Although nothing is known of a "cricket season" ''per se'' in 1598, cricket was being played in the south-east of England at the time and so 1598 was the first season, as such, since the sport's earliest known reference. The sparse information available about the early years suggests that it may have been a children's game in the 16th century but, by 1611, it had become an adult pastime. The earliest known organised match was played circa 1611, a year in which other significant references to the sport are dated. From 1611 to 1725, fewer than thirty matches are known to have been organised between recognised teams. Similarly, only a limited number of players, teams and venues of the period have been recorded. The earliest matches played by English parish teams are examples of [[village cricket]]. Although village matches are now considered minor in status, the early matches are significant in cricket's history simply because they are known. There were no newspaper reports of matches until the end of the seventeenth century and so the primary sources are court records and private diaries, hence games were rarely recorded.<ref name="matches" group="fc">Note that the information in this article is subject to change in the light of ongoing research. Surviving match records as late as 1825 are incomplete and, for example, any statistical compilation of a player's career to then can only be based on ''known'' data. Match [[scoring (cricket)|scorecards]] have survived from 1744 but were not always created, or have been lost, and the matches themselves were not always recorded in the press or other media. Well into the 19th century, scorecard data was not comprehensive: e.g., [[bowling (cricket)|bowling analyses]] lacked [[delivery (cricket)|balls bowled]] and [[run (cricket)|runs conceded]]; bowlers were not credited with [[wicket]]s when the [[batting (cricket)|batsman]] was [[caught]] or [[stumped]]; in many matches, the mode of [[dismissal (cricket)|dismissal]] was omitted.</ref>
[[File:Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond, by circle of Jean Marc Nattier.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond]] was a leading patron of early cricket.]] During the reign of [[Charles I of England|Charles I]], the gentry took an increased interest as patrons and occasionally as players. A big attraction for them was the opportunity that the game offered for [[gambling]] and this escalated in the years following the [[Restoration (England)|Restoration]] when cricket in London and the south-eastern counties of England evolved into a popular social activity. The [[patronage|patrons]] staged lucrative eleven-a-side matches featuring the earliest [[Amateur status in first-class cricket|professional players]]. Meanwhile, English colonists had introduced cricket to North America and the [[Caribbean|West Indies]], and the sailors and traders of the [[East India Company]] had taken it to the [[Indian subcontinent]].
In the first quarter of the 18th century, more information about cricket became available as the growing newspaper industry took an interest. The sport noticeably began to spread throughout England as the century went on. By 1725, significant patrons such as [[Edwin Stead]], [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond]] and [[Sir William Gage, 7th Baronet|Sir William Gage]] were forming teams of county strength in [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] and [[Sussex county cricket teams|Sussex]]. The earliest known great players, including [[William Bedle]] and [[Thomas Waymark]], were active. Cricket was attracting large, vociferous crowds and the matches were social occasions at which gambling and [[alcoholic drink]]s were additional attractions.
==Origins of cricket as a children's game== [[File:EdwardII-Cassell.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Edward II (depicted in Cassell's ''History of England'') played ''creag'' in his youth.]] The most widely accepted theory about the origin of cricket is that it first developed in early medieval times to the south and south-east of London in the geographical areas of the [[North Downs]], the [[South Downs]] and the [[Weald]].<ref name=DU4>{{cite book |last=Underdown |first=David |authorlink=David Underdown |title=Start of Play |year=2000 |publisher=Allen Lane |isbn=0-7139-9330-8 |page=4}}</ref> The counties of Kent, Sussex and Surrey were therefore the earliest centres of excellence and it was from here that the game reached London, where its lasting popularity was ensured, and other southern counties like [[Berkshire]], Essex, [[Hampshire]] and [[Middlesex]]. As early as c.1611, a cricket match was recorded at [[Chevening]] in Kent between teams representing the Downs and the Weald.<ref name=DU4/>
A number of words in common use at the time are thought to be possible sources for the name "cricket". In the earliest known reference to the sport in 1598, it is called ''creckett''. Given the strong medieval trade connections between south-east England and the [[County of Flanders]] when the latter belonged to the [[Duchy of Burgundy]], the name may have been derived from the [[Middle Dutch]]<ref>[[Middle Dutch]] was the language in use in Flanders at the time.</ref> ''krick''(''-e''), meaning a stick; or the [[Old English]] ''cricc'' or ''cryce'' meaning a crutch or staff.<ref name=DB3>{{cite book |last=Birley |first=Derek |authorlink=Derek Birley |title=A Social History of English Cricket |year=1999 |publisher=Aurum |isbn=1-85410-710-0 |page=3}}</ref> In what may be an early reference to the sport, a 1533 poem attributed to [[John Skelton]] describes Flemish weavers as "kings of crekettes", a word of apparent Middle Dutch origin.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7919429.stm |first=Chris |last=Mason |title=Cricket was invented in Belgium |date=2 March 2009 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=9 July 2013}}</ref> In [[Samuel Johnson]]'s ''Dictionary of the English Language'' (1755), he derived cricket from "''cryce'', Saxon, a stick".<ref name=HSA21>{{cite book |last=Altham |first=H. S. |authorlink=Harry Altham |title=A History of Cricket, Volume 1 (to 1914) |year=1962 |publisher=George Allen & Unwin |isbn= |page=21}}</ref> In [[Old French]], the word ''criquet'' seems to have meant a kind of club or stick, though this may have been the origin of [[croquet]].<ref name=DB3/> Another possible source is the Middle Dutch word ''krickstoel'', meaning a long low stool used for kneeling in church, the shape of which resembled the two [[stump (cricket)|stump]] [[wicket]] used in early cricket.<ref>{{cite book |last=Bowen |first=Rowland |authorlink=Rowland Bowen |title=Cricket: A History of its Growth and Development |year=1970 |publisher=Eyre & Spottiswoode |isbn= |page=33}}</ref> According to Heiner Gillmeister, a European language expert of the [[University of Bonn]], "cricket" derives from the Middle Dutch phrase for [[hockey]], ''met de (krik ket)sen'' (i.e., "with the stick chase").<ref name=Terry>{{cite web|url=http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/SportsHistorian/2000/sh201e.pdf |title=The Seventeenth Century Game of Cricket: A Reconstruction of the Game |last=Terry |first=David |publisher=SportsLibrary |date=2008 |accessdate=25 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5laxwhCZO?url=http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/SportsHistorian/2000/sh201e.pdf |archivedate=27 November 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Gillmeister believes the sport itself had a Flemish origin but "the jury is still out" on the matter.<ref name=L1597>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1300.html#1597 |title=From Lads to Lord's: 1597 |last=Leach |first=John |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2007 |accessdate=4 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140053/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1300.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Cricket was probably devised by children and survived for many generations as essentially a children's game.<ref name=HSA24>Altham, p. 24.</ref> Possibly it was derived from [[bowls]], assuming bowls is the older sport, by the intervention of a batsman trying to stop the ball reaching its target by hitting it away. Playing on sheep-grazed land or in clearings, the original implements may have been a matted lump of sheep's wool (or even a stone or a small lump of wood) as the ball; a stick or a crook or another farm tool as the bat; and a gate (e.g., a wicket gate), a stool or a tree stump as the wicket. The invention of the game could have happened in Norman or Plantagenet times anytime before 1300; or even in Saxon times before 1066.<ref>{{cite book |title=On Cricket |last=Arlott |first=John |authorlink=John Arlott |last2=Trueman |first2=Fred |authorlink2=Fred Trueman |year=1977 |publisher=BBC Books |isbn= |page=1}}</ref>
All acknowledged subject experts and authorities agree that there is no evidence of cricket having evolved from another bat-and-ball sport and, equally, no evidence that any other bat-and-ball sport evolved from cricket. The authorities include writers [[Harry Altham]], [[John Arlott]], [[Derek Birley]], [[Arthur Haygarth]], [[David Underdown]], [[Roy Webber]] and [[Peter Wynne-Thomas]]. Their consensus view is that the only thing that can definitely be said about the origin of cricket is that its earliest record is in a late 16th-century court case in Surrey which proves it was played by children in southeast England in the middle of that century.<ref>Birley, p. 5.</ref><ref name=HSA21/><ref>{{cite book |last=Major |first=John |authorlink=John Major |title=More Than A Game |year=2007 |publisher=HarperCollins |isbn= |page=17}}</ref><ref name=DU3>Underdown, p. 3.</ref> There have been alternative theories of origin but these have been dismissed or ignored by authorities. For example, the writer [[Andrew Lang]] claimed in 1912 that cricket evolved from a bat-and-ball game which may have been played in [[Dál Riata]] as early as the 6th century and this claim has been dismissed, by Anthony Bateman among others, in terms of "Lang's idiosyncratic belief in the [[Celts|Celtic]] origin of cricket".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neuroscience-arena.com/journals/pdf/papers/rsih_article.pdf |first=Anthony |last=Bateman |title=More Mighty Than The Bat, The Pen |publisher=British Society of Sports History |date=2003 |accessdate=12 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150217220412/http://www.neuroscience-arena.com/journals/pdf/papers/rsih_article.pdf |archivedate=17 February 2015 |df= }}</ref> It is true that cricket is one of many bat-and-ball sports existing worldwide which have no known origin. Others are the definitely Celtic sports of [[hurling]] and [[shinty]]. [[Golf]] and [[hockey]] are other British ball games involving a club or stick while [[croquet]] was apparently imported from France and globally there are games such as Sweden's [[brännboll]], Italy's [[:it:Lippa (gioco)|lippa]], India's [[gilli-danda]], Finland's [[pesäpallo]] and Samoa's [[kilikiti]]. However, it is generally believed that cricket essentially belongs to the same family of bat-and-ball games as [[stoolball]], [[rounders]] and [[baseball]] but whether it evolved from any of these, or ''vice versa'', cannot be determined.<ref name=HSA20>Altham, p. 20.</ref> There is a 1523 reference to stoolball at a designated field in [[Oxfordshire]]; this may then have been a generic term for any game in which a ball is somehow hit with a bat or stick.<ref name=RB261/> 18th century references to stoolball in conjunction with cricket clearly indicate that it was a separate activity.<ref>{{cite book |last=McCann |first=Tim |authorlink=Timothy J. McCann |title=Sussex Cricket in the Eighteenth Century |year=2004 |publisher=Sussex Record Society |isbn= |pages=37, 121, 126}}</ref>
==="Creag"=== On Thursday, 10 March 1300 ([[Julian calendar]]), wardrobe accounts of King [[Edward I of England]] included refunds to one John de Leek of monies that he had paid out to enable [[Edward II of England|Prince Edward]] to play "creag and other games" at both [[Westminster]] and [[Newenden]].<ref name=HSA20/> Prince Edward, the future Prince of Wales, was then aged 15. It has been suggested that "creag" was an early form of cricket.<ref>Bowen, p. 29.</ref> However, creag could have been something quite different.<ref name=JM18>Major, p. 18.</ref> Creag is possibly an early spelling of the word ''[[craic]]'' here taken as an Irish word meaning [[fun]], entertainment, or enjoyable conversation.<ref name=L1597/> This [[word sense|sense]] of the word ''crack'' is found in [[Irish English]], [[Scottish English]], and [[Geordie]] in [[North East England]]. In Ireland the spelling ''craic'' is now more common than ''crack''.<ref>[[Oxford English Dictionary]] – "crack ([[noun]])" sense I.5.c.</ref>
===Earliest definite references=== [[File:RGS old building.jpg|250px|right|thumb|The Royal Grammar School in Guildford where John Derrick was a pupil when he and his friends played "creckett" circa 1550.]] The earliest definite reference to cricket being played anywhere in England (and hence anywhere in the world) is in evidence given at a 1597 [[legal case]], concerning ownership of a parcel of land, which confirms that it was played on [[common land]] in [[Guildford]], [[Surrey]], around 1550.<ref name=HSA21/> The court in Guildford heard on Monday, 17 January 1597 (Julian date, equating to the year 1598 in the Gregorian calendar) from a 59-year-old [[coroner]], [[John Derrick]], who gave witness that when he was a scholar at the "Free School at Guildford", fifty years earlier, "hee and diverse of his fellows did runne and play [on the common land] at creckett and other plaies", confirming that the sport was played there by schoolboys c.1550. It is perhaps significant that cricket is the only one of the "plaies" to be specifically named.<ref name=JM19>Major, p. 19.</ref><ref name=DU3/>
In 1598, there was a reference to cricket in an Italian-English dictionary by [[John Florio|Giovanni Florio]]. His definition of the word {{lang|it|sgillare}} was: "to make a noise as a [[cricket (insect)|cricket]], to play ''cricket-a-wicket'', and be merry".<ref name=Florio/> Florio is the first writer known to have defined "cricket" in terms of both an insect and a game. In a later edition of his dictionary in 1611, Florio infers that "to play cricket-a-wicket" has sexual associations with references to ''{{not a typo|frittfritt}}'', defined "as we say cricket a wicket, or ''{{not a typo|gigaioggie}}''", and ''{{not a typo|dibatticare}}'', defined "to thrum a wench lustily till the bed cry ''{{not a typo|giggaioggie}}''".<ref name=Florio>{{cite web |url=http://www.pbm.com/~lindahl/florio/ |title=Queen Anna's New World of Words, f. 144 and f. 198 |date=1611 |first=Giovanni |last=Florio |accessdate=29 September 2008}}</ref>
==The development of village cricket: 1611–1660== ===Beginning of adult participation=== [[File:Oliver Cromwell by Robert Walker.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Oliver Cromwell]] was the subject of the earliest definite reference to cricket being played in [[London]].]] The first definite mention of cricket in [[Kent]] is deduced from a 1640 court case which recorded a "cricketing" of "the Weald and the Upland" versus "the Chalk Hill" at [[Chevening, Kent|Chevening]] "about thirty years since" (i.e., c.1611). This is the earliest known [[village cricket]] match; and the earliest known organised match in Kent, in England and in the world. Inter-parish contests became popular in the first half of the 17th century. As with the 1597 reference, the case concerned the land on which the game was played. The 1611 season as such was the fourteenth since the sport's earliest definite reference in 1597.<ref name=DU4/>
In 1611, a French-English dictionary was published by [[Randle Cotgrave]] who defined the noun ''crosse'' as "the crooked staff wherewith boys play at cricket"; the verb form of the word is ''crosser'', defined as "to play at cricket".<ref name=HSA22/><ref name=JM31>Major, p. 31.</ref> Although cricket was defined as a boys' game in Cotgrave's dictionary, as per the Guildford schoolboys above, it was at this time that adult participation is known to have begun.<ref name=L1597/>
In 1613, a court case recorded that someone was assaulted with a "cricket staffe" at [[Wanborough, Surrey|Wanborough]], near Guildford.<ref name=TJM1>McCann, p. xxxi.</ref> In 1616, [[John Bullokar]] referred to cricket in his ''[[An English Expositor]]'' as "a kind of game with a ball".<ref>Altham, pp. 21–22.</ref> In 1617, the 18-year-old [[Oliver Cromwell]] is recorded as playing cricket and [[football]] in [[London]]. This is the earliest definite reference to cricket in London.<ref name=HSA22>Altham, p. 22.</ref>
In 1624, a fatality occurred following a match on Saturday, 28 August, at [[Horsted Keynes]], now in [[East Sussex]]. A fielder called [[Jasper Vinall]] was struck on the head by the batsman, Edward Tye, who was trying to hit the ball a second time to avoid being [[caught]]. Vinall, who died thirteen days later at home in [[West Hoathly]], is thus the earliest recorded cricketing fatality. The matter was recorded in a [[coroner's court]], which returned a verdict of [[death by misadventure]].<ref name=TJM2>McCann, pp. xxxiii–xxxiv.</ref> The tragedy was repeated in 1647 when another fatality was recorded at [[Selsey]], now in West Sussex, a player called Henry Brand being hit on the head by a batsman trying to hit the ball a second time.<ref>McCann, p. xxxix.</ref> When the first ''[[Laws of Cricket]]'' were encoded in 1744, it was illegal to hit the ball twice and a batsman breaking the rule was to be given out.<ref>{{cite book |last=Haygarth |first=Arthur |authorlink=Arthur Haygarth |title=Scores & Biographies, Volume 1 (1744–1826) |year=1862 |publisher=Lillywhite |isbn=1-900592-23-1 |page=xvi}}</ref> The record of the 1624 case confirms that two villages, Horsted Keynes and West Hoathly, were involved in the match and provides further evidence of the growth of village cricket.<ref name=TJM2/>
===Breaking the Sabbath=== The first definite mention of cricket in [[Sussex]] was in 1611 and relates to [[ecclesiastical court]] records stating that two parishioners of [[Sidlesham]], now in [[West Sussex]], had failed to attend church on [[Easter|Easter Sunday]] because they were playing cricket. They were fined 12 [[Penny (English coin)|pence]] each and made to do [[penance]], which meant confessing their guilt to the whole church congregation the following Sunday.<ref name=DB7>Birley, p. 7.</ref> The case is the first of several 17th century cricket references, until the [[Restoration (England)|Restoration]] in 1660, arising from [[Puritans|Puritan disapproval]] of recreational activity, especially on Sundays. These references indicate that inter-parish matches were being played but there is nothing to suggest that any [[county cricket|teams representative of counties]] were formed before the Restoration.<ref name=OMC/> There is no evidence of large scale gambling or patronage prior to the English Civil War and it was those factors which drove the formation of "representative" teams in the 18th century. It must be concluded, therefore, that the cricket being played before the war was of ''minor'' standard only: i.e., village cricket.<ref name=OMC/>
Puritan interference had become enough of a problem by 1617 for [[James VI and I|James I]] to issue the ''[[Declaration of Sports]]'' (also known as ''The Book of Sports'') which listed the sports and recreations that were permitted "on Sundays and other holy days". Initially, the declaration was effective in [[Lancashire]] only, partly as a reaction to Puritan suppression there of [[football]] (i.e., "mob football" in those days), blood sports and other activities which encouraged [[gambling]]. In 1618, the declaration was issued nationally and then reissued by [[Charles I of England|Charles I]] in 1633. Cricket is not mentioned, although its near relation [[bowls]] is on the prohibited list. The omission of cricket provides evidence as such that it was still an obscure regional activity. The ''Declaration of Sports'' was strongly opposed by the Puritans, who were becoming increasingly influential. The purpose of the declaration was to rebuke the Puritans and prevent them from interfering in the people's lawful recreations. It had limited success until the [[English Civil War|Civil War]] began in 1642. The Puritans were by then in control of Parliament which closed the theatres and issued sanctions against other recreational activities although, again, there was no mention of cricket except when individual players were accused of "breaking the Sabbath". The ''Declaration of Sports'' manuscript was publicly burned by order of the Puritan Parliament in 1643.<ref name=DB7/><ref>Major, p. 23.</ref>
In 1622, several parishioners of [[Boxgrove]], near [[Chichester]] in west Sussex, were prosecuted for playing cricket in a churchyard on Sunday, 5 May. There were three reasons for the prosecution: one was that it contravened a local bye-law; another reflected concern about church windows which may or may not have been broken; the third was that ''a little childe had like to have her braines beaten out with a cricket batt''!<ref name=TJM1/> The latter reason was because the rules at the time allowed the batsman to [[hit the ball twice]] and so fielding near the batsman was very hazardous, as the incidents involving Jasper Vinall and Henry Brand were to drastically confirm.
In 1628, an ecclesiastical case related to a game at [[East Lavant]], near [[Chichester]] in West Sussex, being played on a Sunday. One of the defendants argued that he had not played during evening prayer time but only before and after. It did him no good as he was fined the statutory 12d and ordered to do penance.<ref>McCann, pp. xxxiv–xxxvii.</ref>
There are three further references before the Civil War. In a 1636 court case concerning a tithe dispute, a witness called Henry Mabbinck testified that he played cricket "in the Parke" at [[West Horsley]] in Surrey.<ref name="RB262"/> Another ecclesiastical case recorded parishioners of [[Midhurst]], West Sussex, playing cricket during evening prayer on Sunday, 26 February 1637 (i.e., Julian date).<ref>McCann, pp. xxxviii–xxxix.</ref> In 1640, Puritan clerics at both [[Maidstone]] and [[Harbledown]], near [[Canterbury]], denounced cricket as "profane", especially if played on Sunday.<ref>Underdown, pp. 11–12.</ref>
When the [[English Civil War]] began in 1642, the [[Long Parliament]] banned theatres, as they had met with Puritan disapproval. Although similar action would be taken against certain sports, there is no evidence of cricket having been prohibited. Except that players must not "break the Sabbath", references to the game before and during the [[Commonwealth of England|Commonwealth]] suggest that it was approved; and Cromwell himself (see above) had been a player as a young man.
In 1654, three men were prosecuted at [[Eltham]] in Kent for playing cricket on a Sunday. As the Puritans were now firmly in power, Cromwell's [[Protectorate]] having been established the previous year, the penalty was doubled to 24 pence (two [[Shilling (British coin)|shillings]]). The defendants were charged with "breaking the Sabbath", not with playing cricket. There is no evidence that cricket, unlike the theatres and other forms of entertainment, was banned by the Puritans.<ref>Birley, p. 9.</ref> Similarly, when Cromwell's commissioners banned sport in Ireland two years later on the grounds of "unlawful assembly", there is no evidence that the ban included cricket, which had probably not reached Ireland by that time.<ref>Bowen, p. 267, records 1792 as the date of the earliest known match in Ireland.</ref>
Puritan prejudice did not survive the Restoration. In 1671, a man called Edward Bound was charged with playing cricket on the Sabbath and was exonerated: evidence that attitudes had changed. The case was reported in [[Shere]], Surrey.<ref name="JM31"/>
===The beginning of amateur cricket=== The beginnings of cricket's social division between amateurs and professionals, from which the annual [[Gentlemen v Players]] contest ultimately evolved, can be traced to the reign of [[Charles I of England|Charles I]]. In 1629, Henry Cuffin, a curate at [[Ruckinge]] in Kent, was prosecuted by an archdeacon's court for playing cricket on Sunday evening after prayers. He claimed that several of his fellow players were "persons of repute and fashion".<ref name=B45>Bowen, p. 45.</ref><ref name="DB7"/> This statement is the first evidence of cricket achieving popularity among the gentry.<ref name=B45/>
It was the gentry who introduced large-scale [[gambling]] into cricket and some of these gamblers subsequently became [[patronage|patrons]] by forming select teams that would improve their chances of winning. During the [[Commonwealth of England|Commonwealth]], gambling was, of political necessity, low key. The earliest reference to gambling on a cricket match is in the records of a 1646 court case concerning non-payment of a wager that was made on a game at [[Coxheath]] in Kent on Friday, 29 May that year. Curiously, considering the huge sums of money staked later in the century, this wager was for twelve candles, but the participants included members of the local gentry. The match at Coxheath is the earliest known example of an "odds" game as two Coxheath players were against four Maidstone players; the Coxheath II won. It was possibly a [[single wicket cricket|single wicket]] match and, if that could be proved, it would be the earliest on record.<ref name=RB47>Bowen, p. 47.</ref>
In 1652, a case at [[Cranbrook, Kent|Cranbrook]] against John Rabson, Esq. and others referred to "a certain unlawful game called cricket". Rabson was evidently a member of the gentry but the other defendants were all working class.<ref>Underdown, p. 15.</ref> Cricket has long been recognised as a sport that bridged the class divide but, in time, the cricketing gentlemen came to be called "[[Amateur status in first-class cricket|amateurs]]" to emphasise the distinction between themselves and the professionals who belonged to the lower social classes, mostly to the working class.<ref>Birley, pp. 26–30.</ref> The amateur became not merely someone who played cricket in his spare time but a particular type of top-class cricketer who existed officially until 1962, when the distinction between amateur and professional was abolished and all the then [[first-class cricket|first-class]] players became nominally professional. In terms of remuneration, amateurs claimed expenses for playing while professionals were paid a salary or fee.<ref name=DB291>Birley, p. 291–292.</ref> Amateur cricket was an extension of the game played in schools, universities and other centres of education, both as a curricular and extracurricular activity. The schools and universities formed the "production line" that created nearly all the top-class amateur players.<ref name=DB291/>
[[File:John Churchill in his thirties.jpg|thumb|left|John Churchill as a young man. He played cricket at school in the 1660s.]] There are few 17th century references to cricket being played at or in the vicinity of schools but, in 1647, a Latin poem contains a probable reference to cricket being played at [[Winchester College]]; if so, it is the earliest known mention of cricket in [[Hampshire]].<ref>Birley, p. 10.</ref> There is a reference to the game at [[St Paul's School, London]] c.1665 concerning [[John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough]], who studied there.<ref>{{cite book |last=Wisden |title=Wisden Cricketers' Almanack, 100th edition |edition=1963 |editor-last=Preston |editor-first=Norman |editor-link=Norman Preston |publisher=Sporting Handbooks Ltd |location=London |page=178}}</ref> In his ''Social History of English Cricket'', Derek Birley comments that school cricket was "alive and well during the interregnum" (1649–1660). He speculates that the game "must have been known to every schoolboy in the south-east" of England. He doubts, however, that the sport at this time was part of any school's curriculum. Apart from [[Eton College]] and [[Westminster School]], all schools in the 17th century had local intakes and no class segregation. Therefore, the sons of rich and poor families played together.<ref>Birley, pp. 9–10.</ref> As evidenced by the legal cases of 1646 and 1652, described above, cricket was played jointly by gentry and workers.
The earliest reference to cricket at [[Oxford University]] is dated 1673.<ref>{{cite book |last=Maun |first=Ian |authorlink=Ian Maun |title=From Commons to Lord's, Volume One: 1700 to 1750 |year=2009 |publisher=Roger Heavens |isbn=978-1-900592-52-9 |page=15}}</ref> In [[John Phillips (author)|John Phillips]]' ''Duellum Musicum'', a 1673 pamphlet concerning music tuition, there is a criticism of his rival [[Thomas Salmon (musicologist)|Thomas Salmon]], who had boasted of being a graduate of [[Trinity College, Oxford]]: <blockquote>"He shews but a slender sign of his University-Education: Where he seems to have spent his time rather in the more laudable Exercises of Trap and Cricket, than in any sound Reading".</blockquote> Depending on when Salmon graduated, it would seem that cricket was a normal activity at Oxford for some time before Phillips wrote his pamphlet.<ref>{{cite book |last=Wilson |first=Martin |title=Rewriting History |year=2007 |publisher=Association of Cricket Statisticians and Historians |work=The Cricket Statistician, no. 139}}</ref> It was certainly well established at Oxford by October 1728 when the 19-year-old [[Samuel Johnson]] entered [[Pembroke College, Oxford|Pembroke College]]. He told [[James Boswell]] that cricket matches were played during the one year he was at Oxford and this was recorded by Boswell in his ''Life of Samuel Johnson''.<ref>Maun, p. 38.</ref> A comment by [[Horace Walpole]] confirms that cricket was being played at [[Eton College|Eton]] during the first quarter of the 18th century.<ref>Altham, p. 66.</ref> The earliest reference to cricket being played at [[Cambridge University]] is dated 1710 and both of those establishments were attended by [[William Goldwin]] who, in 1706, wrote a Latin poem of 95 lines on a rural cricket match. It was called ''In Certamen Pilae'' (On a Ball Game) and it was published in his ''Musae Juveniles''.<ref name="Altham, pp. 24–25">Altham, pp. 24–25.</ref>
==The development of important cricket: 1660–1700== It was during the second half of the 17th century that, as Roy Webber put it, "the game took a real grip" especially in the south-eastern counties.<ref name=W10>{{cite book |last=Webber |first=Roy |authorlink=Roy Webber |title=The Phoenix History of Cricket |year=1960 |publisher=Phoenix |isbn= |page=10}}</ref> The nobility withdrew to their country estates during the Commonwealth and were involved in village cricket as a pastime which, after the Commonwealth expired in 1660, they took with them when they returned to London.<ref name=W10/>
The Restoration of the monarchy in England in 1660 was immediately followed by the reopening of the theatres and sanctions imposed by the Puritans on sports were also lifted.<ref name=OMC/> Cricket was a leading entertainment and "it was ideal for a wager".<ref name=OMC>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1601.html#restoration |title=From Lads to Lord's: Cricket Since the Restoration |first=John |last=Leach |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2007 |accessdate=10 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140259/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1601.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> According to [[Rowland Bowen]], "it is likely that the Restoration was the crucial factor in leading to the social acceptance of the game".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152818.html |title=Wisden 1965 : Cricket in the 17th and 18th centuries |last=Bowen |first=Rowland |authorlink=Rowland Bowen |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |date=1965}}</ref> Although there are only scattered references to the game in the time of [[Charles II of England|Charles II]], it is clear that its popularity was increasing and that it was expanding.<ref name=B11>Birley, p. 11.</ref>
The Restoration was effectively completed during the spring of 1660 and, in the general euphoria which both accompanied and followed these historic events, gambling on cricket and other sports was freely pursued.<ref name=B11/> The large amounts at stake led some investors to try to improve their chances of winning by forming teams that were stronger than the typical parish XI.<ref name=OMC/> By now, the nobility had adopted cricket as one of their main sports along with [[horse racing]] and [[bare-knuckle boxing|prizefighting]].<ref name=W10/> This was the beginning of the patronage that sustained and controlled cricket through the 18th century.<ref name=OMC/> The first teams representing several parishes and even whole counties were formed in the 1660s and the period saw the first "great matches" as cricket evolved into a major sport.<ref name=HSA23>Altham, p. 23.</ref>
A significant aspect of this evolution was the introduction of [[Amateur status in first-class cricket|professionalism]].<ref name=OMC/> Members of the nobility who returned to London after the Restoration were keen to develop cricket and brought with them some of the "local experts" from village cricket whom they now employed as professional players.<ref name=HSA23/> Within a year or two of the Restoration, "it became the thing in London society to make matches and form clubs".<ref name=HSA23/> A kind of "feudal patronage" was established as the nobility took control of the sport, their interest fuelled by the opportunities for gambling that it provided, and this set the pattern for cricket's development through the next century.<ref name=HSA23/> Consequently, there was a significant rise in standards of play to the level that is now termed [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important]].<ref name="status" group="fc">[[First-class cricket]] was officially defined in May 1894 by a meeting at [[Lord's]] of [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC) and the [[county cricket|county clubs]] which were then competing in the [[County Championship]]. The ruling was effective from the beginning of the 1895 season. Pre-1895 matches of the same standard have no official definition of status because the ruling is not retrospective and the [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important match]] designation, as applied to a given match, is based on the views of one or more substantial historical sources. For further information, see [[First-class cricket]], [[Forms of cricket]] and [[History of cricket]].</ref>
The Gaming Act 1664 was passed by the "Cavalier" Parliament to try and curb some of the post-Restoration excesses.<ref name=L64>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1601.html#1661 |title=From Lads to Lord's: 1664 |first=John |last=Leach |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2007 |accessdate=10 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140259/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1601.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> It limited stakes to £100 which was in any case a fortune at the time,<ref name=B11/> equivalent to about £{{formatprice|{{inflation|UK|100|1664|r=-3}}}} in present-day terms.{{inflation-fn|UK}} It is known that cricket could attract stakes of 50 guineas by 1697 and it was funded by gambling throughout the next century.<ref name=FL18C1>{{cite book |last=Buckley |first=G. B. |authorlink=G. B. Buckley |title=Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket |year=1935 |publisher=Cotterell |isbn= |page=1}}</ref>
[[File:Richgreen.jpg|thumb|240px|right|Cricket was played on Richmond Green in 1666.]] The shortage of references in the latter part of the 17th century is due to the [[Licensing of the Press Act 1662]] which imposed very stringent controls on the newspaper industry.<ref name=L96>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1601.html#1693 |title=From Lads to Lord's: 1696 |first=John |last=Leach |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2007 |accessdate=10 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140259/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1601.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> Sport, including cricket, was not a subject to be reported and the few references found are in official records, such as court cases, or in private letters and diaries. In May 1666, [[Robert Paston, 1st Earl of Yarmouth|Sir Robert Paston]] of [[Richmond, London|Richmond]] wrote a letter to his wife mentioning "a game of criquett (''sic'') on Richmond Green" which is the first reference to cricket at [[Richmond Green cricket ground|Richmond Green]], a popular venue for important matches during the 17th and 18th centuries.<ref name=L66>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1601.html#richmond |title=From Lads to Lord's – Richmond Green |last=Leach |first=John |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2007 |accessdate=11 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140522/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1601.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref>
There was a significant development at Maidstone on Saturday, 28 March 1668 when the [[quarter session]]s made a ruling that [[HM Customs and Excise|customs and excise]] could not claim [[excise|excise duty]] on alcoholic drinks sold at a "kricketing"; it was further ruled that a match promoter had the right to sell ale to spectators, presumably after obtaining the necessary licence. As John Major suggested, this dealt a massive blow to "Puritan morality", and it could have been the beginning of the long-term relationship between sport and alcohol.<ref>Major, p. 36.</ref> Derek Birley's comment on the excise ruling was that cricket's "connection with [[pub|public houses]] is historic in every sense of the word". In his view, the sport had "arrived" because the [[brewery]] trade was the earliest and strongest [[Sponsor (commercial)|sponsor]] of popular sport.<ref>Birley, p. 12.</ref>
In 1677, accounts of [[Thomas Lennard, 1st Earl of Sussex]], include an item which refers to £3 being paid to him when he went to a cricket match being played at "ye Dicker", which was a common near [[Herstmonceux]] in East Sussex.<ref>McCann, p. xl.</ref> In 1678, there was mention of cricket as "a play" (presumably in the sense of a sport that is played) in a Latin dictionary published by Dr [[Adam Littleton]]. In 1694, accounts of Sir John Pelham record 2s 6d paid for a wager concerning a cricket match at [[Lewes]].<ref name=TJM3>McCann, p. xli.</ref>
[[Mitcham Cricket Club]] was formed in 1685, the club playing on what is today known as [[Mitcham Cricket Green]]. The site has hosted cricket matches ever since.<ref name=PhilShaw>{{cite web|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20020713/ai_n12629473 |title=Cricket: After 400 years, history is made next to the A323 |first=Phil |last=Shaw |publisher=The Independent |date=13 July 2003 |accessdate=6 February 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006000955/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20020713/ai_n12629473 |archivedate= 6 October 2007 |df= }} Quote: "Mitcham Green has been in continual use as a cricket venue for 317 years".</ref> Mitcham is believed to be the world's oldest cricket club as there is no evidence of any club being founded before 1685. [[Croydon Cricket Club|Croydon]], [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] and [[London Cricket Club|London]] had all been founded by the 1720s but their dates of origin have been lost, although there was an actual reference to a London Club in 1722.<ref>In a letter to ''The Weekly Journal'' (London) dated 21 July 1722.</ref>
[[File:Artillery Ground in 2008.jpg|right|thumb|250px|The [[Artillery Ground]] photographed in 2008.]] London Cricket Club was to become chiefly associated with the [[Artillery Ground]] in [[Finsbury]]. This venue was first mentioned re cricket on Friday, 7 May 1725, when the minutes of the [[Honourable Artillery Company]] referred to its being used for cricket: there is a note which concerns "the abuse done to the herbage of the ground by the cricket players".<ref name=IM3031>Maun, pp. 30–31.</ref> The Artillery Ground became the feature venue for cricket in the mid-18th century.<ref>Altham, pp. 29–30.</ref>
In 1695, Parliament decided against a renewal of the [[Licensing of the Press Act 1662|1662 Licensing Act]] and so cleared the way for [[Freedom of the press|a free press]] on the Act's expiry in 1696. Censorship had already been relaxed following the [[Bill of Rights 1689]]. It was from this time that cricket matters could be reported in the newspapers, but it would be a very long time before the newspaper industry adapted sufficiently to provide frequent, let alone comprehensive, reports.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/statutes-realm/vol5/pp428-435 |title=Charles II, 1662: An Act for preventing the frequent Abuses in printing seditious treasonable and unlicensed Bookes and Pamphlets and for regulating of Printing and Printing Presses |publisher=British History Online |work=Statutes of the Realm: Volume 5 |date=1628–80 |accessdate=4 November 2016}}</ref> The earliest known newspaper report of a "great match" was in the ''Foreign Post'' dated Wednesday, 7 July 1697:<ref name=FL18C1/><ref name=TJM3/>
<blockquote>"The middle of last week (i.e., probably on Wednesday, 30 June 1697) a great match at cricket was played in Sussex; there were eleven of a side, and they played for fifty guineas apiece".</blockquote>
A historically significant event which is recorded by numerous sources, starting with [[G. B. Buckley]] in his ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket'', it is the world's earliest known [[first-class cricket|important cricket match]] (possibly [[Sussex county cricket teams|Sussex]] v [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] or [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]]) and, as Buckley said, "the earliest record of an eleven a side match".<ref name=FL18C1/> The stakes on offer confirm the importance of the fixture and the fact that it was eleven-a-side suggests that two strong and well-balanced teams were assembled.<ref name=TJM3/> No other details were given but the report provides real evidence to support the view that "great matches" played for high stakes were in vogue in the years following the Restoration.<ref name=L97/> Given the Sussex venue, [[Charles Lennox, 1st Duke of Richmond]] may have been one of the patrons involved.<ref name=L97>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1601.html#1697 |title=From Lads to Lord's: 1697 |date=2007 |first=John |last=Leach |publisher=Stumpsite |accessdate=28 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140259/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1601.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> Following the decision of the English government in 1695 to allow freedom of the press (i.e., they decided not to renew the [[Licensing of the Press Act 1662]] which had inhibited the scope of publications), it was possible for sporting events to be reported; however, it was a long time before editors gave sport any priority so coverage remained low key and infrequent for several decades. The 1697 match occurred in the 100th season since cricket's earliest definite reference in 1597.
Periodicals called ''The Post Boy'' and ''The Post Man'' were in circulation during the early 18th century. In 1700, a series of ten-a-side matches to be held on [[Clapham Common]], near [[Vauxhall]], was pre-announced on Saturday, 30 March, by ''The Post Boy''. The first was to take place on Easter Monday, 1 April, and prizes of £10 and £20 were at stake. No match reports could be found so the results and scores remain unknown. The advert says the teams would consist of ten "Gentlemen" per side but the invitation to attend was to "Gentlemen and others". This clearly implies that cricket had achieved both the patronage that underwrote it through the 18th century and the spectators who demonstrated its lasting popular appeal. As the event involved "gentlemen only", it was probably minor in quality but is nevertheless the earliest known organised match in the county of [[Surrey]].<ref name=W4>{{cite book |last=Waghorn |first=H. T. |authorlink=H. T. Waghorn |title=The Dawn of Cricket |year=1906 |publisher=Electric Press |isbn= |page=4}}</ref>
==Rules and equipment of early cricket== Early [[cricket]]ers played in their everyday clothes and had no protective equipment such as gloves or pads. A 1743 painting of a game in progress at the [[Artillery Ground]] depicts two [[batting (cricket)|batsmen]] and a [[bowling (cricket)|bowler]] dressed alike in white shirt, breeches, white knee-length stockings and shoes with buckles. The [[wicket-keeper]] wears the same clothes with the addition of a waistcoat. An [[umpire (cricket)|umpire]] and [[Scoring (cricket)|scorer]] wear three-quarter length coats and tricorn hats. Apart from the shirts and stockings, none of the clothes are white and no one wears pads or gloves. The [[cricket ball|ball]] is bowled [[underarm bowling|underarm]] along the ground, as in [[bowls]], at varying speed towards a [[wicket]] consisting of two [[stump (cricket)|stumps]] mounted by a single [[Bail (cricket)|crosspiece]]. The batsman addresses the delivery with a [[cricket bat|bat]] that resembles a modern [[hockey stick]], this shape being ideal for dealing with a ball on the ground.<ref>The painting is [[Francis Hayman]]'s ''Cricket at the Artillery Ground'', 1743. It hangs at [[Lord's Cricket Ground]].</ref> The modern straight bat evolved in the 1760s after [[Pitched delivery bowling in cricket|bowlers began to "give the ball air" by pitching it]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1751.html#bowling |title=From Lads to Lord's – The first bowling revolution |last=Leach |first=John |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2007 |accessdate=11 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140122/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1751.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> As a result, "the game changed completely and evolved from its [[Pioneering phase (cricket)|pioneering phase]] into what may be termed its pre-modern phase".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1751.html#bowling |title=From Lads to Lord's – 1760 |last=Leach |first=John |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2007 |accessdate=11 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140122/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1751.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:Oldest cricket bat.JPG|right|thumb|250px|The [[cricket bat]] of the 1720s was shaped like a modern [[hockey stick]] so that it could address a ball that was not pitched.]] The record of the 1622 case at Boxgrove contains the earliest reference to the [[cricket bat]]. The term "batt" in cricket was peculiar to Kent and Sussex, where coastal smugglers were known as "batmen" because of the cudgels they carried. The earliest reference to a "flat-faced" bat (i.e., with a flat surface at the bottom of the stick in [[ice hockey]] style) also occurs in 1622.<ref>{{cite book |last=Martineau |first=G. D. |title=Bat, Ball, Wicket and All |publisher=Sporting Handbooks |year=1950}}</ref> The term "bat" remained comparatively rare until about 1720. The terms in more general use were "staff", "stave" or "stick". These tended to have regional usage: for example, "stave" was used in the Gloucester area and "batt" in the south-east; while "staff" and especially "stick" were more widely used.<ref name=Terry/> "Bat" is derived from the French "battledore", shaped like a table tennis bat, which was used by washerwomen to beat their washing with.<ref>Oxford Dictionary of English – "battledore".</ref>
The earliest reference to the [[cricket ball]] is found in 1658 in ''Mysteries of Love and Eloquence'' by [[Edward Phillips]].<ref name=HSA22/> The [[cricket pitch|pitch]] has been 22 yards long (i.e., a [[Chain (unit)|chain]]) since the first known code of Laws in 1744<ref name=Wisden>{{cite web |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/153476.html |title=Dates in Cricket History |publisher=Wisden Cricketer's Almanack |date=1978 |accessdate=29 September 2008}}</ref> and it is believed this length had been in use since the introduction of [[Gunter's chain]] in 1620.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bLbo4sr-xfwC&pg=PA27&lpg=PA27&dq=gunter's+chain+cricket+pitch&source=web&ots=DMpgOZyCXJ&sig=V5xqhjHTB41AUBxFVAmny5OAlFg&hl=en |title=Australian Popular Culture |last=Craven |first=Ian, Martin Gray and Geraldine Stoneham | work=British Australian Studies Association |date=1994 |publisher=Cambridge University Press Popular Culture |isbn=0-521-46667-9 |page=27 |accessdate=29 September 2008}}</ref> The [[Over (cricket)|over]] consisted of four deliveries until the 19th century.<ref name=Wisden/>
The earliest known reference to the [[wicket]] is contained in lines written in an old bible in 1680 which invited "All you that do delight in Cricket, come to [[Marden, West Sussex|Marden]], pitch your wickets".<ref>Waghorn, p. 3.</ref> Marden is in West Sussex, north of Chichester, and close to [[Hambledon, Hampshire|Hambledon]], which is just across the county boundary in Hampshire. The wicket until the 1770s comprised two stumps and a single bail. By that time, the shape of the wicket was high and narrow after the 1744 Laws defined the dimensions as 22 inches high and six inches wide. But earlier 18th century pictures show a wicket that was low and broad, perhaps two feet wide by one foot high. The ends of the stumps were forked to support the light bail and there were criteria for the firmness of pitching the stumps into the ground and for the delicate placing of the bail so that it would easily topple when a stump was hit.<ref name=Terry/>
There has been a lot of conjecture about the origin of the wicket, but suffice to say that the 17th century outline shape is more akin to the profile of a church stool, which is low and broad. Furthermore, the legs of the stool were called stumps, which adds further credence to the idea that stools were used as early wickets.<ref name=Terry/> According to the ''Churchwarden's Accounts for Great St. Mary's Church of Cambridge'' (1504–1635), a church stool was sometimes known in the south-east by the Dutch name of "kreckett", this being the same word used for the game by John Derrick in 1597.<ref name=Terry/>
The earliest known mention of the [[umpire (cricket)|umpire]] dates from 1680 and is the first entry in Buckley's ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket''. Buckley does not quote the reference "that is quite unfit for publication nowadays" but he confirms a clear reference to "the two umpires" and that the double wicket form of the game was already well known in London. It is also the first mention of cricket in the county of [[Middlesex]].<ref name=FL18C1/>
There were two main [[forms of cricket]] in the 17th and 18th centuries. One was [[single wicket cricket|single wicket]] in which, as the name implies, there is only one batsman, although teams of threes or fives often took part. The converse is the "double wicket" form, with two batsmen, and this has long been associated with eleven-a-side teams playing two innings each and it is these games which, depending on the teams involved, have [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important match status]].<ref name=ACS4>{{cite book |last=ACS |authorlink=Association of Cricket Statisticians and Historians |title=A Guide to Important Cricket Matches Played in the British Isles 1709 – 1863 |year=1981 |publisher=ACS |location=Nottingham |isbn= |pages=4–5}}</ref> Although single wicket was in vogue through the period of this history, the earliest ''definite'' record of a single wicket match is in 1726, so it is out of scope in this article.<ref name=IM33/>
In early cricket, there were two [[Umpire (cricket)|umpires]] as now, but the modern square-leg umpire stood close to the striker's wicket. Both umpires carried a bat which the running batsman was required to touch in order to complete his run.<ref>Altham, p. 27.</ref> There were two [[scorer]]s who sat on the field and recorded the scores by making notches on tallysticks; runs were then known as notches for this reason.<ref>Altham, p. 28.</ref>
==English cricket in the early 18th century== ===Patrons=== [[File:Charles Lennox, 1st Duke of Richmond and Lennox by Sir Godfrey Kneller, Bt.jpg|thumb|180px|right|Charles Lennox, 1st Duke of Richmond.]] On an unknown date in 1702, the [[1st Duke of Richmond's XI cricket team|1st Duke of Richmond's XI]] defeated an [[Arundel Cricket Club|Arundel XI]] at an unspecified venue in Sussex. The source for this game is a receipt sent by one Saul Bradley to the Duke on Monday, 14 December 1702. The receipt was for one [[shilling]] and six [[pence]] paid by the Duke "for brandy when your Grace plaid at Cricket with Arundel men". It is thought the brandy was bought to celebrate a victory. The venue was probably either [[Goodwood House|Goodwood]], where Richmond had his estate, or [[Arundel]], possibly on [[Bury Hill, Arundel|Bury Hill]] which was used for cricket in later years. Arundel was a prominent centre of cricket in the 18th century.<ref>McCann, p. 1.</ref>
After the 1st Duke of Richmond died in 1723, his son [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond]], quickly succeeded him as cricket's main benefactor and became a famous patron of Sussex cricket for the next thirty years. The 2nd Duke enjoyed a friendly rivalry with his friend [[Sir William Gage, 7th Baronet|Sir William Gage]], another Sussex patron. Their teams played each other many times and their earliest known contest was on Tuesday, 20 July 1725, five days after Sir William's team was beaten by unknown opponents. Richmond wrote to Gage in early July 1725 and issued a challenge for a match to be played at [[Goodwood House|Goodwood]]. Gage replied to him by letter on 16 July and confirmed that his team would play the Duke's on Tuesday, 20 July. Gage then stated that he is "in great affliction from being shamefully beaten yesterday (Thursday, 15 July 1725) the first match I played ys (''sic'') year". He went on to wish the Duke success in everything except his cricket match. The game on 20 July was actually played at [[Bury Hill, Arundel]] and Richmond's team won by "above forty (runs)". The report in the ''Daily Journal'' newspaper on Wednesday, 21 July, confirms Bury Hill (then called Berry Hill), near Arundel, as the venue. The match, played before "a vast Concourse of People", was hosted by [[Thomas Howard, 8th Duke of Norfolk]] who gave a ball at [[Arundel Castle]] in the evening. 1725 was English cricket's 128th season since the sport's earliest definite reference in 1597.<ref name=TJM19>McCann, p. 19.</ref><ref name=IM31>Maun, p. 31.</ref>
The main rival to Richmond and Gage was [[Edwin Stead]] of Maidstone, who was the first of the noted Kent patrons. The Sussex teams of Richmond and Gage enjoyed an inter-county rivalry with Stead's Kent that could have originated the concept of the [[County Championship]].<ref>Waghorn, p. 7.</ref>
===The terms of the wager=== The patrons ensured that cricket was financed in the 18th century but their interest, equally applicable to horse racing and prizefighting, was based on the opportunities that cricket provided for gambling. Every important match in the 18th century, whether eleven-a-side or single wicket, was played for stakes. The early newspapers recognised this and were more interested in publishing the odds than the match scores. Reports would say who won the wager rather than who won the match.<ref>Birley, pp. 14–16.</ref>
Sometimes, gambling would lead to dispute and two matches ended up in court when rival interests sought legal rulings on the terms of their wagers. On Monday, 1 September 1718, a game on [[White Conduit Fields]] in [[Islington]] between [[London Cricket Club|London]] and the [[Rochester Punch Club cricket team|Rochester Punch Club]] was unfinished because three Rochester players "made an elopement" in an attempt to have the game declared incomplete so that they would retain their stake money. London was clearly winning at the time. The London players sued for their winnings and the game while incomplete was the subject of a noted lawsuit in which the terms of the wager were at issue. The court ordered that the match must be "played out" and this happened in early July 1719 (the exact date is uncertain but it was before the 4th). Rochester with four wickets standing needed thirty more runs to win but were all out for 9. It is not certain if 30 was their overall target or if they needed thirty more in addition to runs scored in the original encounter; equally, it is not known if 9 was the innings total they achieved or if they added nine more to their "overnight" score. London's 21-run victory is the earliest known definite result of any cricket match. The match is the earliest known mention of White Conduit Fields as a venue.<ref name=ACS19/><ref name=FL18C2>Buckley (FL18C), p. 2.</ref>
In 1724 (exact date unknown), [[Edwin Stead's XI cricket team|Edwin Stead's XI]] v [[Chingford Cricket Club|Chingford]] ended early because the Chingford team refused to play to a finish when Stead's team had the advantage. Another court case followed. It is known that [[John Pratt (judge)|Lord Chief Justice Pratt]] presided over the case and ordered them, as in the London v Rochester match in 1718, to play it out so that all wagers could be fulfilled. Pratt "referr'd the said Cause back to [[Dartford Heath]], to be played on where they left off, and a Rule of Court was made accordingly".<ref name=IM33>Maun, p. 33.</ref> The game was completed in 1726. The final result is not on record, and there is no confirmation that Stead's team held their advantage and won.<ref>Waghorn, pp. 5–6.</ref> This match is the earliest reference to cricket being played in [[Essex]], if [[Chingford]] was the original venue, though it is assumed to have been Dartford Brent. It is certainly the first match known to have involved an [[Essex county cricket teams|Essex team]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/histories/matches.html |title=Classification of cricket matches from 1697 to 1825 |last=Leach |first=John |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2008 |accessdate=11 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140003/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/histories/matches.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 }}</ref>
The introduction of [[Articles of Agreement (cricket)|articles of agreement]], agreed before matches by the stakeholders, largely resolved any problems between patrons and match organisers. The concept was more important in terms of defining the rules of play and eventually these were codified as the ''Laws of Cricket''.<ref>Birley, pp. 18–19.</ref>
===Matches of the early 18th century=== On Tuesday, 24 July 1705, ''The Post Man'' announced [[East and West Kent cricket teams|West of Kent]] v [[Chatham Cricket Club|Chatham]], an 11-a-side game to be played in Kent on Tuesday, 7 August. The primary source gives the venue as "Maulden" which must have been a typeset error as there is no such place. It was possibly [[Maidstone]] or [[West Malling|Malling]]. The title "West of Kent" suggests a team representative of several parishes, so this is arguably the earliest known [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important match]] in Kent. There were several matches throughout the 18th century involving teams called "West Kent" and "East Kent". Chatham was a prominent centre of cricket in the 18th century.<ref name=W4/><ref name=IM7>Maun, p. 7.</ref>
On Thursday, 26 June 1707, there was a [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Mitcham Cricket Club|Mitcham]] match at [[Lamb's Conduit Field]], [[Holborn]]. The result is unknown. This is the earliest known [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important match]] in [[Middlesex]] and possibly the earliest known to involve the original London Cricket Club, though the date of the club's formation is uncertain and the team here might have been an ''ad hoc'' London XI. In contrast to the "[[Non-international England cricket teams|all England]]" term used later in the century, the source calls the team "all London". Mitcham Cricket Club, which is extant, was founded in 1685.<ref name=IM9>Maun, p. 9.</ref>
On Tuesday, 1 and Tuesday, 8 July 1707, [[Croydon Cricket Club|Croydon]] played London twice, the first game played in Croydon, probably at [[Duppas Hill]], and the second at [[Lamb's Conduit Field]] in [[Holborn]]. Both matches were advertised by ''The Post Man'' as "two great matches at cricket (to be) plaid, between London and Croydon; the first at Croydon on Tuesday, 1 July, and the other to be plaid in Lamb's-Conduit-Fields, near Holborn, on the Tuesday following, being the 3rd (''sic'') of July". No post-match reports could be found so the results and scores are unknown. The match in Croydon is the earliest known [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important match]] in [[Surrey]]. As with the previous match, it is not known if the teams at this time represented formally constituted clubs and it is possible that both were ''ad hoc'' teams drawn from local residents. Croydon and London both had important teams in the first half of the 18th century.<ref name=W5>Waghorn, p. 5.</ref><ref name=ACS19>ACS, ''Important Matches'', p. 19.</ref> The match in Holborn was a return to the one on 1 July. There has been some confusion about the date of the second match following a misreading of the original source by [[H. T. Waghorn]], who was the first modern researcher, but Tuesday, 8 July is believed to be correct.<ref>{{cite book |last=Wilson |first=Martin |title=An Index to Waghorn |publisher=Bodyline |year=2005 |page=50}}</ref>
On Wednesday, 23 June 1708, a local match took place somewhere in the [[Canterbury]] area and was recorded in the diary of one Thomas Minter, a Canterbury resident, who wrote: "We beat Ash Street at Crickets (''sic'')". Although this was probably a minor match only, it illustrates the popularity of cricket in Kent.<ref name=W4/><ref name=IM10>Maun, p. 10.</ref>
The earliest known match that definitely involved county teams, or teams using the names of counties, was [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] v [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] at [[Dartford Brent]] on Wednesday, 29 June 1709. This was advertised in the ''Post Man'' the previous Saturday and played for a stake of £50.<ref name=ACS19/><ref name=FLPVC1>{{cite book |last=Buckley |first=G. B. |authorlink=G. B. Buckley |title=Fresh Light on pre-Victorian Cricket |year=1937 |publisher=Cotterell |isbn= |page=1}}</ref> From this time, in the 112th season since the sport's earliest definite reference in 1597, there are references to counties in use as team names although it is generally believed that the earliest "inter-county matches" were really inter-parish matches involving two villages on either side of a county boundary. [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] was an important club in the first half of the 18th century and its team at this time featured [[William Bedle]]. The match is the earliest known mention of Dartford Brent as a venue.<ref name=FLPVC1/><ref>Maun, pp. 11–12.</ref>
One player who could have taken part in the 1709 match was [[William Bedle]] (1680–1768), of Dartford, who is the earliest great player whose name has been recorded. He was "reckoned to be the most expert player in England" and must have been in his prime c.1700 to c.1725.<ref name="Buckley FL18C, p. 48">Buckley (FL18C), p. 48.</ref> Other good players known to have been active in the 1720s were Edwin Stead of Kent; [[Edmund Chapman]] and [[Stephen Dingate]] of Surrey; [[Tim Coleman (18th century cricketer)|Tim Coleman]] of London; and [[Thomas Waymark]] of Sussex.
Village cricket continued to thrive in the 18th century. On Friday, 31 May 1717, Thomas Marchant, a farmer from [[Hurstpierpoint]] in Sussex, first mentioned cricket in his diary. He made numerous references to the game, particularly concerning his local club, until 1727. His son Will played for "our parish", as he often called the Hurstpierpoint team. In total, his diaries mention 21 village matches and the entries provide evidence of the widespread popularity of cricket in Sussex.<ref name=TJM1717>McCann, pp. 1–5.</ref> It is from the 1717 season that a continuous history of English cricket by season is possible. Records of cricket have survived from every season after 1716, although the details in most seasons through the 18th century remain sparse.
===Dartford v London=== The first great rivalry in cricket history was between the [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] and [[London Cricket Club|London]] clubs who are first known to have played each other in 1722. London played some matches against [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] but the county side is believed to have largely consisted of Dartford players. On Wednesday, 19 August 1719, London v Kent was played at [[White Conduit Fields]] and Kent won. The report said the teams played for "a considerable sum of money". There is an insight into the priorities of early 18th century cricketers as the contemporary report concludes with: "The Kentish men won the wager" (i.e., the wager was more important than the match).<ref name=W5/>
On Saturday, 9 July 1720, London v Kent at White Conduit Fields was won by London.<ref name=ACS19/> In this match, two London [[fielding (cricket)|fielders]] were badly injured by a clash of heads.<ref name=W5/> [[H. T. Waghorn]] noted a lull in the advertising and reporting of cricket after this game and he wondered if that was due to a perception that the sport was dangerous.<ref name=W5/> If there was a lapse in cricket at this time, the more likely causes would be either: (a) the [[South Sea Bubble]] which ruined many investors and so could have reduced cricket patronage; or (b), as Waghorn himself mentions, "the (news)papers were small, and space limited, the advertising and reporting (of) matches ceased". The [[South Sea Company|South Sea Bubble]] may have had an economic impact on investment and gambling as, when the South Sea Company was found to be insolvent, its crash in 1720 caused massive repercussions throughout the economy and many formerly prosperous investors were ruined.<ref>Birley, p. 16.</ref> This could have included cricket patrons, while a potential impact on reporting was the application of [[stamp duty]] to newspapers as this increased their publication costs and probably caused publishers to reduce paper size with less room for sports coverage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1701.html#1720 |title=From Lads to Lord's: 1720 |date=2007 |first=John |last=Leach |publisher=Stumpsite |accessdate=10 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140522/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1701.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref>
On Wednesday, 18 July 1722, London v Dartford was the subject of a letter in ''The Weekly Journal'' dated Saturday, 21 July 1722. It is believed the match took place somewhere in the [[Islington]] area, so the exact venue may have been [[White Conduit Fields]]. The match was abandoned following a dispute. The letter said: "A Match at Cricket was made between the little Parish of Dartford in Kent, and the Gentlemen known by the name of the London Club". Teams styled "London" were already in existence, as above, but this is the first actual reference to a "London Club".<ref name=ACS19/><ref name=DCC/><ref name=IM26>Maun, pp. 26–27.</ref>
Dartford and London met at [[Dartford Brent]] on Thursday, 11 June 1724<ref name=IM28>Maun, p. 28.</ref> and, one week later, a return game was the earliest known match at [[Kennington Common]], near where [[The Oval]] is now sited. The results of both matches are unknown.<ref name=ACS19/><ref name=FL18C3>Buckley (FL18C), p. 3.</ref>
===Other matches in the 1720s=== On Wednesday, 6 July 1720, [[Kingston Cricket Club|Kingston]] v [[Richmond Cricket Club (18th century)|Richmond]] was played at an unknown venue and Kingston won.<ref name=IM23>Maun, p. 23.</ref> The secondary source is uncertain about the date due to a slight ambiguity in the primary source, a contemporary newspaper published Saturday, 16 July, which refers to "Wednesday last". The date of the match must therefore be either 6 or 13 July. The source says 5 or 12 July but this is an error as those dates were Tuesdays. Kingston and Richmond both had important teams in the first half of the 18th century.
There was a [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] v [[London Cricket Club|London]] match at [[Moulsey Hurst]] on an unknown date in 1723. The result is unknown. The source states that "XI Gentlemen of Surrey played XI of London at Moulsey Hurst during the summer". It is the earliest known mention of Moulsey Hurst as a venue for cricket.<ref name=IM27>Maun, p. 27.</ref>
In 1723, the prominent [[Tory]] politician [[Robert Harley, 1st Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer|Robert Harley, Earl of Oxford]] recorded in his journal: "At Dartford upon the Heath as we came out of the town, the men of Tonbridge and the Dartford men were warmly engaged at the sport of cricket, which of all the people of England the Kentish folk are the most renowned for, and of all the Kentish men, the men of Dartford lay claim to the greatest excellence".<ref name=DCC>{{cite web |url=http://www.dartfordcc.co.uk/our-history/club-history |title=Dartford Cricket Club History |publisher=Dartford Cricket Club |accessdate=29 September 2008}}</ref> It is more than likely to have been Dartford Brent where this game was taking place.<ref name=DCC/>
On Monday, 10 August 1724, there was a match at [[Penshurst Park]] (result unknown) which featured the combined parishes of [[Penshurst, Tonbridge & Wadhurst cricket team|Penshurst, Tonbridge & Wadhurst]] versus Dartford. This was recorded in a diary entry by one John Dawson, who may have watched it. No details are known but Mr Dawson says it was "a great cricket match". Note that some sources have mistakenly given the venue as "Islington" but contemporary newspapers confirm that it took place at Penshurst Park.<ref name=TJM18>McCann, p. 4.</ref>
==The growth of cricket in England and overseas== The earliest known mention of cricket being played outside England is dated Saturday, 6 May 1676. A diarist called Henry Tonge, who was part of a British mission at [[Aleppo]] in the Ottoman Empire (now in [[Syria]]), recorded that "at least forty of the English" left the city for recreational purposes and, having found a nice place to pitch a tent for dinner, they "had several pastimes and sports" including "krickett". At six they "returned home in good order".<ref>Haygarth, p. vi.</ref>
By this time, cricket had been introduced to India, North America<ref>Simon Worrall, {{cite web |url=http://www.smithsonianmagazine.com/issues/2006/october/cricket.php |title=Cricket, Anyone? |publisher=Smithsonian Institution Magazine |date=October 2006 |accessdate=30 March 2007}}</ref> and the [[Caribbean|West Indies]] but the first definite references occur in the 18th century. In 1709, cricket was played by [[William Byrd II|William Byrd]] of Westover on his [[James River]] estates in [[Virginia]], then a British colony. This is the earliest reference to cricket being played in the New World.<ref>William Byrd, ''The Secret Diary of William Byrd of Westover'', Dietz Publishing, 1941, pp. 144–146.</ref> There had not been any English colonisation of Australasia or southern Africa, where [[Test cricket]] is played now, by 1725.<ref name=RB261/> Australia and New Zealand had been partly explored by [[Abel Tasman]] in the 1640s<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gutenberg.net.au/pages/tasman.html |title=Abel Tasman |publisher=Project Gutenberg of Australia |accessdate=29 September 2008}}</ref> but still had only their [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginal]] and [[Maori people|Maori]] inhabitants respectively. The first European settlement in South Africa was founded on Tuesday, 6 April 1652 when the [[Dutch East India Company]] established [[Cape Colony]] on [[Table Bay]], near present-day [[Cape Town]].<ref>Roger B. Beck, ''The History of South Africa'', Greenwood, 2000.</ref>
In 1721, British sailors of the [[East India Company]] were reported to be playing cricket at [[Khambhat|Cambay]], near [[Vadodara|Baroda]], and this is the earliest reference to cricket being played in the Indian sub-continent. One of the players wrote: "When my boat was lying for a fortnight in one of the channels, though the country was inhabited by the Culeys (''sic''), we every day diverted ourselves with playing Cricket and to other Exercises, which they would come and be spectators of".<ref name=RG3>{{cite book |last=Guha |first=Ramachandra |authorlink=Ramachandra Guha |title=A Corner of a Foreign Field – An Indian History of a British Sport |year=2001 |publisher=Picador |isbn= |page=3}}</ref>
It is possible that cricket was introduced to the Americas and India before it had spread throughout the British Isles. For example, there is no record of cricket in [[Yorkshire]], home of the English game's most successful [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|club]], until 1751. The earliest mentions of cricket in Ireland, Scotland and Wales occur even later in the 18th century.<ref name=RB261>Bowen, pp. 261–267.</ref>
While Britain's seafaring and trading concerns ensured the spread of cricket overseas, at home it relied heavily on ease of transport and communications, most of these being waterborne as long journeys tended to be undertaken using coastal or river vessels.<ref name=L1706/> Road transport was slowly improving and, in 1706, Parliament established the first [[turnpike trusts]] that placed a length of road under the control of trustees drawn from local landowners and traders.<ref>William Albert, ''The Turnpike Road System in England 1663–1840'', Cambridge University Press, 1972.</ref> The turnpike trusts borrowed capital for road maintenance against the security of tolls. This arrangement became the common method of road maintenance for the next 150 years and came in time to assist the spread of cricket throughout Britain.<ref name=L1706>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1701.html#1706 |title=From Lads to Lord's: 1706 |date=2007 |first=John |last=Leach |publisher=Stumpsite |accessdate=17 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140522/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1701.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==Summary of known organised matches (1611–1725)== The table below is fully chronological. It summarises all of the 27 known organised matches from 1611 to 1725 and does not separate matches by form or status. It therefore includes examples of both "[[first-class cricket|important]]" and "minor" matches, bearing in mind that some minor matches are historically significant. Unless specified as such, "impromptu" games amongst friends, practice matches, etc. are excluded.<ref name=ACS4/> Although [[single wicket cricket|single wicket]] was in vogue at the time, the earliest definite record of a single wicket match is in 1726.<ref name=IM33/>
{| border="1" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! style="width:15.0%; text-align:right;"| date ! style="width:35.0%; text-align:left;"| match title ! style="width:22.5%; text-align:left;"| venue ! style="width:25.0%; text-align:left;"| result ! style="width:2.50%; text-align:right;"| source |- | style="text-align:right;"| unknown date, c.1611 | [[Weald and Upland cricket team|Weald and Upland]] v [[Chalkhill cricket team|Chalkhill]] | [[Chevening, Kent|Chevening]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=DU4/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The earliest known [[village cricket]] match; and the earliest known organised match in [[Kent]], in England and in the world. Deduced from a 1640 court case which recorded a "cricketing" of "Weald and Upland" ''versus'' "Chalkhill" at Chevening "about thirty years since" (i.e., c.1611). As with the 1597 reference (see "Other events" below), the case concerned the land on which the game was played. The 1611 season as such was the fourteenth since the sport's earliest definite reference in 1597. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 28 August 1624 (Sa) | Horsted Keynes v West Hoathly | [[Horsted Keynes]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=TJM2/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The earliest definite mention of cricket in [[Sussex]] is dated 1611 but this is believed to be the earliest known ''organised match'' in the county. Knowledge of it stems from the death thirteen days later of [[Jasper Vinall]], on whom an inquest was held. He had suffered a head injury during the game when accidentally hit by the [[cricket bat|bat]]. As Vinall came from [[West Hoathly]], it is ''assumed'' that the event was a village cricket match between the two parish teams. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 29 May 1646 (F) | Coxheath II v Maidstone IV | [[Coxheath Common]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=RB47/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The earliest known example of an "odds" game as two Coxheath players were against four Maidstone players. Possibly a [[single wicket cricket|single wicket match]] and, if so, the earliest known. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| c.30 June 1697 (W) | "A Great Match" | [[Sussex]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=FL18C1/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | A historically significant event which is recorded by numerous sources, starting with [[G. B. Buckley]] in his FL18C. It is the world's earliest known [[first-class cricket|important cricket match]] (possibly [[Sussex county cricket teams|Sussex]] v [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] or [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]]) and, as Buckley said, "the earliest record of an eleven a side match". Following the decision of the English government in 1695 to allow freedom of the press (i.e., they decided not to renew the [[Licensing of the Press Act 1662]] which had inhibited the scope of publications), it was possible for sporting events to be reported; however, it was a long time before editors gave sport any priority so coverage remained low key and infrequent for several decades. The 1697 match was reported in a periodical called the ''Foreign Post'' and described as "a great match at cricket" that was played "the middle of last week" in Sussex with "eleven of a side" and "they played for fifty guineas apiece".
