The stakes on offer indicate the importance of the fixture and the fact that it was eleven a side suggests that two strong and well-balanced teams were assembled. There is no scorecard and hence no statistics, so the match is outside the scope of the sport's ''statistical'' record, but it is the earliest-known example of an important match in the ''historical'' record and occurred in the 100th season since the sport's earliest definite reference in 1597. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 1 April 1700 (M) | series of ten-a-side matches | [[Clapham Common]], near [[Vauxhall]] | results unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=W4/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The participants were all "gentlemen" though "others" could attend as spectators. Classification is uncertain, though it must presumably be viewed as a minor event given the limited social status of the participants, the relatively low stakes (£10 and £20 are mentioned in the newspaper report) and the ten-a-side teams. It is nevertheless the earliest known organised match in [[Surrey]]; the earliest ''definite mention'' of cricket in the county was the [[John Derrick|1597 court case in Guildford]]. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| unknown date, 1702 | [[1st Duke of Richmond's XI cricket team|1st Duke of Richmond's XI]] v [[Arundel Cricket Club|Arundel]] | [[Sussex]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=TJM1/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Verified by a receipt for the purchase of brandy which describes the purpose of the transaction (i.e., to celebrate a cricket match). The venue was probably either [[Goodwood House|Goodwood]], where Richmond had his estate, or [[Arundel]], possibly on [[Bury Hill, Arundel|Bury Hill]] which was used for cricket in later years. Arundel was a prominent centre of cricket in the 18th century. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 7 August 1705 (Tu) | [[East and West Kent cricket teams|West of Kent]] v [[Chatham Cricket Club|Chatham]] | Maulden (''sic'') | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=IM7/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The primary source gives the venue as "Maulden" which almost certainly refers to [[West Malling|Town Malling]]. The title "West of Kent" suggests a team representative of several parishes, so this is arguably the earliest known important match in Kent. There were several matches throughout the 18th century involving teams called "West Kent" and "East Kent". Chatham was a prominent centre of cricket in the 18th century. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 26 June 1707 (Th) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Mitcham Cricket Club|Mitcham]] | [[Lamb's Conduit Field]], [[Holborn]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=IM9/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The earliest known important match in [[Middlesex]] and possibly the earliest known to involve the original London Cricket Club, though the date of the club's formation is uncertain and the team here might have been an ''ad hoc'' London XI. Given the "All England" term used later in the century, the source calls the team "All London". Mitcham Cricket Club, which is extant, was founded in 1685. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 1 July 1707 (Tu) | [[Croydon Cricket Club|Croydon]] v [[London Cricket Club|London]] | [[Croydon]], possibly [[Duppas Hill]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=W5/><ref name=ACS19/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The earliest known important match in [[Surrey]]. As with the previous match, it is not known if the teams at this time represented formally constituted clubs and it is possible that both were ''ad hoc'' teams drawn from local residents. Croydon and London both had important teams in the first half of the 18th century. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 8 July 1707 (Tu) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Croydon Cricket Club|Croydon]] | [[Lamb's Conduit Field]], [[Holborn]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=W5/><ref name=ACS19/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | A return match to the one on 1 July above. There has been some confusion about the date following a misreading of the original source by [[H. T. Waghorn]], who was the first modern researcher, but Tuesday, 8 July is believed to be correct. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 23 June 1708 (W) | A [[Canterbury]] team v Ash Street | venue unknown | A Canterbury team won | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=W4/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Probably a minor local match only but it illustrates the popularity of cricket in Kent. The original source is the diary of one Thomas Minter, a [[Canterbury]] resident, who wrote: "We beat Ash Street at Crickets (''sic'')". |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 29 June 1709 (W) | [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] v [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] | [[Dartford Brent]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=ACS19/><ref name=FLPVC1/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | From this time, in the 112th season since the sport's earliest definite reference in 1597, there are references to counties in use as team names although it is generally believed that the earliest "inter-county matches" were really inter-parish matches involving two villages on either side of a county boundary.<ref name=PVC1>Buckley (FLPVC), p. 1.</ref> [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] was an important club in the first half of the 18th century and its team at this time featured [[William Bedle]]. The match is the earliest known mention of Dartford Brent as a venue. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 31 May 1717 (F) | "A cricket match" | [[Sussex]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=TJM1717/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Thomas Marchant, a farmer from [[Hurstpierpoint]] in Sussex, first mentioned cricket in his diary. He made numerous references to the game, particularly concerning his local club, until 1727. His son Will played for "our parish", as he invariably called the Hurstpierpoint team. In total, his diaries mention 21 village matches and the entries provide evidence of the widespread popularity of cricket in Sussex.
It is from the 1717 season that a continuous history of English cricket by season is possible. Records of cricket have survived from every season after 1716, although the details in most seasons through the 18th century remain sparse. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 1 Sept 1718 (M) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Rochester Punch Club cricket team|Rochester Punch Club]] | [[White Conduit Fields]] | match abandoned | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=ACS19/><ref name=FL18C2/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | This match is the earliest known mention of White Conduit Fields as a venue. The game was abandoned on Monday, 1 September 1718, because three Rochester players "made an elopement" in an attempt to have the game declared incomplete so that they would retain their stake money. London was clearly winning at the time. The London players sued for their winnings and the game while incomplete was the subject of a noted lawsuit in which the terms of the wager were at issue. The court ordered that the match must be "played out" (see next entry). |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| early July 1719 | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Rochester Punch Club cricket team|Rochester Punch Club]] | [[White Conduit Fields]] | London won by 21 runs | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=ACS19/><ref name=FL18C2/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The continuation of the September 1718 match (see above entry), which was abandoned by the Rochester players. Following a legal action in which the London players sued for their winnings, the court ordered that the match must be "played out". The exact date in July 1719 is uncertain but it was before the 4th. Rochester with four wickets standing needed 30 to win but were all out for 9. It is not certain if 30 was their overall target or if they needed thirty more in addition to runs scored in the original encounter; equally, it is not known if 9 was the innings total they achieved or if they added nine more to their "overnight" score. London's 21-run victory is the earliest known definite result of any cricket match. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 19 August 1719 (W) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | [[White Conduit Fields]] | Kent won | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=W5/><ref name=ACS19/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Reportedly played for "a considerable sum of money". There is an insight into the priorities of early 18th century cricketers as the contemporary report concludes with: "The Kentish men won the wager" (i.e., the wager was more important than the match). |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 6 July 1720 (W) | [[Kingston Cricket Club|Kingston]] v [[Richmond Cricket Club (18th century)|Richmond]] | venue unknown | Kingston won | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=IM23/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The secondary source is uncertain about the date due to a slight ambiguity in the primary source, a contemporary newspaper published Saturday, 16 July, which refers to "Wednesday last". The date of the match must therefore be either 6 or 13 July. The source says 5 or 12 July but this is an error as those dates were Tuesdays. Kingston and Richmond both had important teams in the first half of the 18th century. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 9 July 1720 (Sa) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | [[White Conduit Fields]] | London won | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=W5/><ref name=ACS19/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Two London [[fielding (cricket)|fielders]] were seriously injured by a clash of heads when chasing the ball. Waghorn speculated that their injuries may have caused a perception that the sport is "dangerous" as the next report he could find was for a match in 1726. If there was a lapse in cricket at this time, the more likely causes would be either: (a) the [[South Sea Bubble]] which ruined many investors and so could have reduced cricket patronage; or (b), as Waghorn himself mentions, "the (news)papers were small, and space limited, the advertising and reporting (of) matches ceased". |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| unknown date, 1721 | English sailors | [[Khambhat|Cambay]], [[India]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=RG3/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Not a match in England, but one involving English sailors of the [[East India Company]], who played a match at [[Khambhat|Cambay]], near [[Vadodara|Baroda]]. It is the earliest known reference to cricket being played in the Indian sub-continent. One of the players wrote: "When my boat was lying for a fortnight in one of the channels, though the country was inhabited by the Culeys (''sic''), we every day diverted ourselves with playing Cricket and to other Exercises, which they would come and be spectators of".<ref name=RG3/> |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 18 July 1722 (W) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] | venue unknown | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=ACS19/><ref name=DCC/><ref name=IM26/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The subject of a letter in ''The Weekly Journal'' dated 21 July 1722. It is believed the match took place somewhere in the [[Islington]] area, so the exact venue may have been [[White Conduit Fields]]. The match was abandoned following a dispute. The letter said: "A Match at Cricket was made between the little Parish of Dartford in Kent, and the Gentlemen known by the name of the London Club". Teams styled "London" were already in existence, as above, but this is the first actual reference to a "London Club". |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| unknown date, 1723 | [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] v [[London Cricket Club|London]] | [[Moulsey Hurst]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=IM27/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The source states that "XI Gentlemen of Surrey played XI of London at Moulsey Hurst during the summer". It is the earliest known mention of Moulsey Hurst as a venue for cricket. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| unknown date, 1723 | [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] v [[Tonbridge Cricket Club|Tonbridge]] | [[Dartford Brent]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=DCC/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The subject of a diary entry by [[Robert Harley, 1st Earl of Oxford and Earl Mortimer|Robert Harley, Earl of Oxford]], who wrote: "At Dartford upon the Heath as we came out of the town, the men of Tonbridge and the Dartford men were warmly engaged at the sport of cricket, which of all the people of England the Kentish folk are the most renowned for, and of all the Kentish men, the men of Dartford lay claim to the greatest excellence". |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 11 June 1724 (Th) | [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] v [[London Cricket Club|London]] | [[Dartford Brent]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=IM28/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | This match is a recent discovery so the next match, which has been in the records a long time, was actually a return. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 18 June 1724 (Th) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] | [[Kennington Common]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=ACS19/><ref name=FL18C3/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The earliest known match on Kennington Common and a return match to the one on 11 June above. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 10 August 1724 (M) | [[Penshurst, Tonbridge & Wadhurst cricket team|Penshurst, Tonbridge & Wadhurst]] v [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] | [[Penshurst Park]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=IM28/><ref name=TJM18/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Recorded in a diary entry by one John Dawson, who may have attended, and described as "a great match". Note that some sources have mistakenly given the venue as "Islington" but contemporary newspapers confirm that it took place at Penshurst Park. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| unknown date, 1724 | [[Edwin Stead's XI cricket team|Edwin Stead's XI]] v [[Chingford Cricket Club|Chingford]] | [[Dartford Brent]] | result unknown | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=W5/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Dartford Brent is ''assumed'' to have been the venue because of the wording used by a primary source (see below). If, however, the venue was in [[Chingford]], then this is the earliest known match in [[Essex]]. In an attempt to nullify the wagers, the Chingford team refused to play to a finish when Stead's team had the advantage. A court case followed and, as in the London v. Rochester match in 1718, it was ordered to be played out so that all wagers could be fulfilled. [[John Pratt (judge)|Lord Chief Justice Pratt]] presided over the case and he "referr'd the said Cause back to Dartford Heath (i.e., Brent), to be played on where they left off, and a Rule of Court was made accordingly".<ref name=IM33>Maun, p. 33.</ref> The game was completed in September 1726. The final result is not on record, and there is no confirmation that Stead's team held their advantage and won. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 15 July 1725 (Th) | [[Sir William Gage's XI cricket team|Sir William Gage's XI]] v another XI | unknown venue | Gage "shamefully beaten" | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=TJM19/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond]] wrote to [[Sir William Gage, 7th Baronet|Sir William Gage]] in July 1725 and issued a challenge for a match to be played at [[Goodwood House|Goodwood]]. Gage replied to him by letter on 16 July and confirmed that his team would play the Duke's on Tuesday, 20 July (see below). Gage then stated that he is "in great affliction from being shamefully beaten yesterday the first match I played ys (''sic'') year". He went on to wish the Duke success in everything except his cricket match. |- | colspan="5" | |- | style="text-align:right;"| 20 July 1725 (Tu) | [[2nd Duke of Richmond's XI cricket team|2nd Duke of Richmond's XI]] v [[Sir William Gage's XI cricket team|Sir William Gage's XI]] | [[Bury Hill, Arundel]] | Richmond's XI won by "above forty" | style="text-align:right;"| <ref name=TJM19/><ref name=IM31/> |- | style="text-align:right;"| ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The subject of Gage's letter to Richmond on 16 July (see above). Richmond had challenged Gage to a match at Goodwood. However, the report in the ''Daily Journal'' newspaper on 21 July confirms Bury Hill (then called Berry Hill), near Arundel, as the venue. The match, played before "a vast Concourse of People", was hosted by [[Thomas Howard, 8th Duke of Norfolk]] who gave a ball at [[Arundel Castle]] in the evening. 1725 was English cricket's 128th season since the sport's earliest definite reference in 1597. |}
==First mentions== As illustrated by the table of matches above, little is known of organised cricket to 1725 because of the lack of newspaper coverage. The shortage of references in the latter part of the 17th century is due to the [[Licensing of the Press Act 1662]] which imposed very stringent controls on the newspaper industry. Sport, including cricket, was not a subject to be reported and the few references found are in official records, such as court cases, or in private letters and diaries.<ref name="L96"/> It follows that equally little is known of clubs and teams, players and locations.
The four bulleted lists below summarise the known participants to 1725 under each heading. The earliest important match that is designated inter-county was in 1709 and the [[Historic counties of England|traditional county]] soon became the key unit of organisation.<ref>Webber, p. 9.</ref> Until 1725, only nine counties (plus [[London]] which has on occasion<ref name="LCC">{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1701.html#london |title=From Lads to Lord's: London Cricket Club |first=John |last=Leach |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2007 |accessdate=17 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140259/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1701.html |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/0/191/First-Class_Matches.html |title=First-class matches played by London County |publisher=CricketArchive |date=2003 |accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref> been equated in status with the counties of [[Middlesex]] and [[Surrey]] for cricketing purposes) had been mentioned in surviving records in connection with cricket and the earliest mention of each is summarised below. Note that all are in the south-eastern quarter of the country. In a similar vein, although not always in association with one of the above matches, those players, venues, clubs and teams known to have been active or in use by 1725 are also listed.
===Counties=== The first definite mentions of cricket in the following [[Historic counties of England|traditional counties]] occurred between 1597 and 1724: * [[Cambridgeshire]] – 1710 at the [[University of Cambridge]]<ref name="Altham, pp. 24–25"/> * [[Essex]] – 1724 re the Chingford v Stead match<ref name=W5/> * [[Hampshire]] – 1647 at [[Winchester College]]<ref name=RB262>Bowen, p. 262.</ref> * [[Kent]] – c.1611 re the match at Chevening<ref name=DU4/> * [[London]] – 1617 re Oliver Cromwell<ref name=HSA22/> * [[Middlesex]] – 1680; also the first mention re [[umpire (cricket)|umpires]]<ref name=FL18C1/> * [[Oxfordshire]] – 1673 at the [[University of Oxford]]<ref>Maun, p. 15.</ref> * [[Surrey]] – 1597 re [[John Derrick]] and the [[Guildford]] court case; the world's earliest definite mention of cricket<ref name=HSA21/><ref name=JM19/> * [[Sussex]] – 1611 re an ecclesiastical court case<ref name="TJM1"/>
===Clubs and teams=== With the exception of [[Mitcham Cricket Club|Mitcham]], club and team foundation dates cannot be determined, but it is known that the following clubs or teams were active during the period: * [[1st Duke of Richmond's XI cricket team|1st Duke of Richmond's XI]]<ref name=TJM1/> * [[2nd Duke of Richmond's XI cricket team|2nd Duke of Richmond's XI]]<ref name="TJM18"/> * [[Arundel Cricket Club|Arundel]]<ref name=TJM1/> * [[Chalkhill cricket team|Chalkhill]]<ref name=DU4/> * [[Chatham Cricket Club|Chatham]]<ref name=IM7/> * [[Chingford Cricket Club|Chingford]]<ref name=W5/> * [[Croydon Cricket Club|Croydon]]<ref name=W5/> * [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]]<ref name=IM26/> * [[Edwin Stead's XI cricket team|Edwin Stead's XI]]<ref name=W5/> * [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]]<ref name=FLPVC1/> * [[Kingston Cricket Club|Kingston]]<ref name=IM23/> * [[London Cricket Club|London]]<ref name=IM9/> * [[Mitcham Cricket Club|Mitcham]] (1685)<ref name=PhilShaw/> * [[Penshurst, Tonbridge & Wadhurst cricket team|Penshurst, Tonbridge & Wadhurst]]<ref name=IM28/> * [[Richmond Cricket Club (18th century)|Richmond]]<ref name=IM23/> * [[Rochester Punch Club cricket team|Rochester Punch Club]]<ref name=FL18C2/> * [[Sir William Gage's XI cricket team|Sir William Gage's XI]]<ref name="TJM18"/> * [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]]<ref name=FLPVC1/> * [[Tonbridge Cricket Club|Tonbridge]]<ref name=DCC/> * [[Weald and Upland cricket team|Weald and Upland]]<ref name=DU4/> * [[East and West Kent cricket teams|West Kent]]<ref name=IM7/>
===Players=== The contemporary sources rarely mentioned players by name but it is known that the following were active during the period: * [[Charles Lennox, 1st Duke of Richmond]] ([[Sussex county cricket teams|Sussex]])<ref name=TJM1/> * [[William Bedle]] ([[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] and [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]])<ref name="Buckley FL18C, p. 48"/> * [[Edwin Stead]] (Kent)<ref name=W5/> * [[William Goodwin (cricketer)|William Goodwin]] ([[Sunbury Cricket Club|Sunbury]] and [[Middlesex county cricket teams|Middlesex]])<ref name=IM29>Maun, p. 29.</ref> * [[Sir William Gage, 7th Baronet]] (Sussex)<ref name="TJM18">McCann, p. 4.</ref> * [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond]] (Sussex)<ref name="TJM18"/> * [[Edmund Chapman]] ([[Chertsey Cricket Club|Chertsey]] and [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]])<ref>Waghorn, p. 31.</ref>
===Venues=== The following venues are known to have been used during the period: * [[Artillery Ground]]<ref name=IM3031/> * [[Bury Hill, Arundel]]<ref name=TJM19/> * [[Chevening, Kent|Chevening]]<ref name=DU4/> * [[Clapham Common]]<ref name=W4/> * [[Coxheath Common]]<ref name=RB47/> * [[Dartford Brent]]<ref name=FLPVC1/> * [[Duppas Hill]]<ref name=W5/> * [[Horsted Keynes]]<ref name=TJM2/> * [[Kennington Common]]<ref name=FL18C3/> * [[Lamb's Conduit Field]]<ref name=IM9/> * "Maulden"<ref name=IM7/> * [[Mitcham Cricket Green]]<ref name=PhilShaw/> * [[Moulsey Hurst]]<ref name=IM27/> * [[Penshurst Park]]<ref name=TJM18/> * [[Richmond Green cricket ground|Richmond Green]]<ref name=L66/> * [[White Conduit Fields]]<ref name=FL18C2/>

{{Infobox Organization |name = International Federation for Interuniversity Sport |image = ifiusstar.png |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = IFIUS |motto = |formation = 1998 |extinction = 2011 |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Antwerp]] ([[Belgium]]) |location = |coords = |region_served = Worldwide |membership = Universities & Colleges |language = English |leader_title = [[#Games Council|President]] |leader_name = Dr. B. Ghadimi
([[Islamic Azad University]]) |main_organ = General Assembly |parent_organization = |affiliations = [[Panathlon International]] |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.ifius.com www.ifius.com] |remarks = }} '''IFIUS (International Federation for Interuniversity Sport)''' was a democratic non profit organisation whose main objective was to organise the yearly [[World Interuniversity Games]], in which teams of students from different Universities and Colleges worldwide competed in different sport competitions. In 2011, IFIUS was disbanded and integrated inside [[Panathlon International|Panathlon]]. == History == Until 2003 the Games were held on Weekends during the year - from 2004 onward the Games were held in a one-week period in October, establishing a true World Championship Format. == Competitions == Official competitions included: * [[Association football|Football]] Men * Football Women * [[Futsal]] Men * [[Basketball]] Men * Basketball Women * [[Volleyball]] Men * Volleyball Women * [[Golf]] and [[Pitch and putt|Pitch & putt]] * Individual golf * Individual pitch and putt {| [[Golf]] and [[Pitch and putt|Pitch&Putt]] | | | | | | | | | | | bgcolor="#3399ff" | | bgcolor="#3399ff" | | bgcolor="#3399ff" | | | |- align="center" | colspan="2" align="left" | Individual golf | | | | | | | | | | | | | bgcolor="#3399ff" | | | |- align="center" | colspan="2" align="left" | Individual pitch and putt | | | | | | | | | | | | | bgcolor="#3399ff" | | | |} == Objectives == The main IFIUS objectives were:
(1) Offer each student in the world the opportunity to compete on an international interuniversity sports level.
(2) Protect the rights of interuniversity sports playing students and universities.
(3) Promote international interuniversity sports in every way it deems fit. == IFIUS Games == {|class="wikitable" !Year !Games !Host City !Host University !Remarks |- |1999 |align=center|[[1999 World Interuniversity Games|1]] |{{flagicon|BEL}} [[Antwerp]] ([[Belgium]]) |''(none)'' |Only [[Association football|Football]] Men competition |- |2000 |align=center|[[2000 World Interuniversity Games|2]] |{{flagicon|FRA}} [[Paris]] ([[France]]) |''(none)'' |Football Women competition added |- |2001 |align=center|[[2001 World Interuniversity Games|3]] |{{flagicon|NED}} [[Amsterdam]] (the [[Netherlands]]) |''(none)'' | |- |2002 |align=center|[[2002 World Interuniversity Games|4]] |{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Barcelona]] ([[Spain]]) |[[Autonomous University of Barcelona]] | |- |2003 |align=center|[[2003 World Interuniversity Games|5]] |{{flagicon|ITA}} [[Rome]] ([[Italy]]) |''(none)'' |[[Futsal]] Men competition added |- |2004 |align=center|[[2004 World Interuniversity Games|6]] |{{flagicon|BEL}} Antwerp (Belgium) |[[University of Antwerp]] | |- |2005 |align=center|[[2005 World Interuniversity Games|7]] |{{flagicon|NED}} [[Rotterdam]] (the Netherlands) |[[INHolland university of applied sciences]]

revision.comment: Disambiguated: [[Brentwood High School]] → [[Brentwood High School (Tennessee)]], [[Franklin High School]] → [[Franklin High School (Tennessee)]]
revision.text:
{{Expand list|date=August 2008}} In 1999 the [[University of Nebraska–Lincoln]] installed '''[[FieldTurf]]''' in [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]]. In 2006, Nebraska installed new FieldTurf that alternates between two shades of green every five yards. [[Texas Tech University]] installed FieldTurf in Jones AT&T Stadium. [[University of Nevada, Reno|Nevada]] installed FieldTurf at its [[Mackay Stadium]] in [[2000 in sports|2000]]. The playing surface had been natural grass for 34 seasons.
FieldTurf was installed at [[Qwest Field]] (originally Seahawks Stadium) in 2002.<ref>[http://o.seattletimes.nwsource.com/sports/seahawks/stadium/construction/turf.html Seahawks Stadium]</ref> The original plans called for a natural grass field at the new stadium, but due to the favorable reactions from players while playing at Husky Stadium, the Seahawks had FieldTurf installed instead.<ref>[http://www.seattlepi.com/othersports/32948_turf27.shtml Showdown looms over turf in new stadium]</ref>
On Tuesday, April 29, 2003, the Georgia World Congress Center Authority announced that it had selected FieldTurf as the new surface for the [[Georgia Dome]], replacing the [[AstroTurf]] surface in use at the Dome since its inception in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fieldturf.com/artificial-turf-news/P1221/gwcc-selects-fieldturf-for-georgia-dome/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726234913/http://www.fieldturf.com/artificial-turf-news/P1221/gwcc-selects-fieldturf-for-georgia-dome/ |archivedate=2011-07-26 |df= }}</ref>
[[Washington State University]] installed FieldTurf at its [[Martin Stadium]] in [[2000 in sports|2000]]. The [[University of Oregon]] installed [[NexTurf]] in [[Autzen Stadium]] in 2001 but the surface did not perform as expected and during remodeling in [[2002 in sports|2002]] it was removed and replaced with FieldTurf. The University of Utah installed FieldTurf in 2002 and replaced it in 2009. [[Colorado State University|Colorado State]] installed FieldTurf at its [[Sonny Lubick Field at Hughes Stadium|Hughes Stadium]] in [[2006 in sports|2006]]. The playing surface had been natural grass for 38 seasons.
The [[New England Patriots]] installed FieldTurf midway into the [[2006 NFL season]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Perillo |first=Paul |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Pats to install FieldTurf for Bears game |work=Patriots Football Weekly |publisher=New England Patriots |date=2006-11-14 |url=http://www.patriots.com/news/index.cfm?ac=latestnewsdetail&pid=22463&pcid=41 |doi= |accessdate=2007-02-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929100042/http://www.patriots.com/news/index.cfm?ac=latestnewsdetail&pid=22463&pcid=41 |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }}</ref> The installation was made during a week when the team was on the road.
In 2004, [[Rutgers Stadium]] in [[Piscataway, New Jersey]] installed FieldTurf where the [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights]] football team plays. In 2007, the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]], a [[Canadian Football League]] (CFL) team, installed FieldTurf in [[Mosaic Stadium at Taylor Field]]. In April 2008, FieldTurf was installed at the new baseball stadium of [[Calvert Hall College High School|Calvert Hall High School]] in [[Towson, Maryland]], designed by [[Baltimore Orioles]] baseball great [[Cal Ripken]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Nelson Coffin |title=No diamond in the rough: Stadium is a jewel |date=2008-04-09 |work=The Towson Times |url=http://news.mywebpal.com/news_tool_v2.cfm?pnpid=659&show=archivedetails&ArchiveID=1353345&om=1 |accessdate=2008-04-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611185102/http://news.mywebpal.com/news_tool_v2.cfm?pnpid=659&show=archivedetails&ArchiveID=1353345&om=1 |archivedate=2011-06-11 |df= }}</ref> {{TOC right}}

revision.comment: /* Winners */the work's name is "The Globe and Mail"; publisher=>work in cite
revision.text:
[[File:Wgretz edit2.jpg|right|200px|thumb|Hockey player [[Wayne Gretzky]] has won the Lou Marsh Trophy four times, more than any other athlete.]] The '''Lou Marsh Trophy''', also known as the '''Lou Marsh Memorial Trophy'''{{cite web|url=http://www.cshof.ca/accessible/collection_trophies_detail.php?i=1 |title=Lou Marsh Memorial Trophy |publisher=[[Canada's Sports Hall of Fame]] |accessdate=2007-12-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206193217/http://www.cshof.ca/accessible/collection_trophies_detail.php?i=1 |archivedate=December 6, 2008 }} and '''Lou Marsh Award''',{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2007/12/11/crosby-loumarshaward.html?ref=rss|title=Sidney Crosby wins Lou Marsh Award|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=2007-12-11|accessdate=2007-12-11}} is a trophy that is awarded annually to Canada's top [[athlete]], professional or amateur. It is awarded by a panel of journalists, with the vote taking place in December. It was first awarded in 1936. It is named in honour of [[Lou Marsh]], a prominent Canadian athlete, referee, and former sports editor of the ''[[Toronto Star]]''. Marsh died in 1936 and the trophy was named in his honour. The trophy is made of black marble and stands around 75 centimetres high. The words "With Pick and Shovel" appear above the engraved names of the winners.{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/News/article/284464|title=Sidney Crosby wins Lou Marsh award|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=2007-12-11|accessdate=2007-12-11}} The voting panel consists of sports media voters from across the country{{cite web|url=http://emailreg.thestar.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?GXHC_gx_session_id_=ea55e2e3fe3ca472&pagename=thestar/Layout/Article_PrintFriendly&c=Article&cid=1165877416160|title=Turin queen reigns in 2006|author=Dave Perkins|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=2006-12-12|accessdate=2007-12-12}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} including representatives from the ''Toronto Star'', ''[[The Canadian Press]]'', [[CJCL|FAN590]], ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]], [[Rogers Sportsnet]], [[The Sports Network|CTV/TSN]], ''[[La Presse (Canada)|La Presse]]'' and the ''[[National Post]]''. The Trophy has been awarded 77 times and won by 60 individual athletes and three pairs. [[Wayne Gretzky]] has won the trophy four times, more than any other athlete, while [[Barbara Ann Scott]] has won the trophy three times, more than any other woman. It was not awarded from 1942 to 1944 due to [[World War II]]. There were ties between different athletes in 1978 and 1983. The most recent winner is [[Joey Votto]], first baseman for the [[Cincinnati Reds]]. ==Winners== [[File:Kurt Browning at the 2010 Stars on Ice (3).jpg|right|150px|thumb|[[Kurt Browning]], 1990 winner]] [[File:Asv-koeln-1997-donovan-bailey.jpg|right|150px|thumb|[[Donovan Bailey]], 1996 winner]] [[File:Jacques Villeneuve Canada 2006.jpg|right|150px|thumb|[[Jacques Villeneuve]], 1995 and 1997 winner]] [[File:Sale pelletier love story.jpg|right|150px|thumb|[[Jamie Salé]] and [[David Pelletier]], 2001 winners]] [[File:Mike Weir by Richard Wayne.jpg|right|150px|thumb|[[Mike Weir]], 2003 winner]] [[File:Adam van Koeverden.jpg|right|150px|thumb|[[Adam van Koeverden]], 2004 winner]] [[File:Steve Nash 2.jpg|right|150px|thumb|[[Steve Nash]], 2005 winner]] [[File:SidneyCrosby.jpg|right|150px|thumb|[[Sidney Crosby]], 2007 and 2009 winner]] [[File:Joey votto-2008.jpg|right|150px|thumb|[[Joey Votto]], 2010 and 2017 winner]] ;Key * '''*''' = Also won the [[Lionel Conacher Award]] as Canadian male athlete of the year * ^ = Also won the [[Bobbie Rosenfeld Award]] as Canadian female athlete of the year {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Winner ! Sport ! Win # |- | 1936 || {{sortname|Phil|Edwards|dab=runner}} * || [[Track and field]] || 1 |- | 1937 || {{sortname|Marshal|Cleland}} || [[Equestrianism|Equestrian]] || 1 |- | 1938 || {{sortname|Bobby|Pearce|dab=rower}} || [[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]] || 1 |- | 1939 || {{sortname|Bob|Pirie}} || [[swimming (sport)|Swimming]] || 1 |- | 1940 || {{sortname|Gérard|Côté||Cote, Gerard}} * || {{Infobox theatre | name = Manila Grand Opera House | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption= | address = 925 [[Rizal Avenue]] corner Doroteo Jose Street | city = [[Manila]] | country = [[Philippines]] | status = Demolished | designation = | latitude = | longitude = | architect = | owner = | tenant = | operator = | capacity = | type = [[Opera house]] | opened = Mid-19th century | reopened = | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = 1970s | othernames = H.T. Hashim’s National Cycle Track (before 1890)
Teatro Nacional (1890-1902) | production = | website = }} The '''Manila Grand Opera House''' ([[Filipino language|Filipino]]: ''Marangal na Bahay-Opera ng Maynila'', abbreviated '''MGOH''') was a [[theater]] and [[opera house]] located in the [[Santa Cruz, Manila|Santa Cruz]] district of [[Manila]] on the intersection of [[Rizal Avenue]] and Doroteo Jose Street. First built in the mid-19th century as a circular wooden structure with a [[Nypa fruticans|nipa]] roof known as the H.T. Hashim’s National Cycle Track, the complex served as the center of Philippine culture and the primary theater for the viewing of plays, movies and [[zarzuela]]s in Manila prior to the construction of the [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]] in the 1960s. The complex had undergone several incarnations and name changes before being demolished. A hotel has since been constructed on the site on where the theater once stood. ==History== [[Image:Taft Addressing First Philippine Assembly 1907.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[William Howard Taft]] addressing the audience at the [[Philippine Assembly]] in the Manila Grand Opera House.]] The Manila Grand Opera House was built in the mid-19th century as the H.T. Hashim’s National Cycle Track, a circular wooden structure with a [[Nypa fruticans|nipa]] roof.{{cite news|author=Santos, Tina |title=Hint of nostalgia on site of Manila Grand Opera House |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20080809-153675/Hint-of-nostalgia-on-site-of-Manila-Grand-Opera-House |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer, Inc. |date=2008-08-09 |accessdate=2008-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522104550/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20080809-153675/Hint-of-nostalgia-on-site-of-Manila-Grand-Opera-House |archivedate=2011-05-22 |df= }} In 1890, the name was changed to the ''Teatro Nacional'' (National Theater), where the Russian Circus and some American theater companies performed. The name was subsequently changed to the Manila Grand Opera House after an extensive expansion of the original theater and its conversion to an opera house in time for the visit of an Italian opera company in 1902, after the American takeover of the Philippines, and was used as the location of the inauguration of the members of the [[Philippine Assembly|First Philippine Assembly]] on October 16, 1907.{{cite news|author=Uckung, Peter Jaynul V. |title=Dominador Gomez rattled the first Philippine Assembly |url=http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2007/oct/16/yehey/opinion/20071016opi7.html |work=[[The Manila Times]] |publisher=Manila Times Publishing Corporation |date=2007-10-16 |accessdate=2008-01-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117064416/http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2007/oct/16/yehey/opinion/20071016opi7.html |archivedate=2008-01-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }} It was in Manila Grand Opera House where the Philippines' pioneer symphonic group, the [[Manila Symphony Orchestra|Manila Symphony Society]], performed its first concert on January 22, 1926.{{cite journal | author=Carrion, Carmita | title=The Manila Symphony Society: 1926-1958 | url=http://www.philippinestudies.net/ojs/index.php/ps/article/view/3094 | work=[[Philippine Studies]] | volume=6 | issue=1 | pages=5–52 | publisher=[[Ateneo de Manila University Press]] | year=1958 | accessdate=3 May 2014 }} The purpose of the concert was to raise funds for the building of the Philippine Constabulary Orchestra's music library. Two important performances in Manila Grand Opera are [[Claro M. Recto]]'s award-winning dramas ''La ruta de Damasco '' and '' Solo entre las sombras '' {{cite journal | author=Matibag, Eugenio | title=STAGING THE NATION: CLARO M. RECTO'S DOMESTIC DRAMAS | url=http://web.a.ebscohost.com/abstract?direct=true&profile=ehost&scope=site&authtype=crawler&jrnl=1656152X&AN=88989770&h=0%2b6tkVLveq3U%2bU83uOBy5dLEYaxu6AMw8%2brvNXL8pU0%2bbgeZx140bSksniG7FFqyiBVRVZ6VzFun0cugOtZdcA%3d%3d&crl=c | work=[[Kritika Kultura]] | issue=20 | pages=172–204 | publisher=[[Ateneo de Manila University Press]] | date=February 2013 | accessdate=2014-05-03 }} Another key event is the convention organized by the socialist and communist parties of the Philippines on November 7, 1938 where both parties officially merged as one, taking the name “[[Partido Komunista ng Pilipinas-1930|Communist Party of the Philippines]]”, which was later renamed Communist Party of the Philippines-1930 (PKP-1930), in order to avoid confusion with [[Communist Party of the Philippines|the splinter group of the same name]]. {{cite journal | title=Pedro B. Abad Santos (1876-1945): Great Labor Leader | url=http://nhcp.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/bz0001.pdf | publisher=[[National Historical Commission of the Philippines]] | year=2012 | accessdate=2 May 2014 }} [[File:LRTstationjf9675 13.JPG|thumb|MGOH viewed from the LRT-1 station]] The theater served as the home for theater productions, operas and zarzuelas in the Manila area until the onset of [[World War II]]. Toribio Teodoro, then referred to as the "shoe king of the Philippines", acquired the property in 1942 and used the MGOH as his residence during the Japanese occupation and the [[Second Philippine Republic]], at which his house and shoe factory were seized by Japanese forces. Floods and a fire damaged the theater in 1943 and 1944, respectively, with reconstruction efforts commencing after the war. By the 1950s, the theater, equipped with state-of-the-art equipment for both theatrical and cinematic productions, was dubbed its famous title "The Theater with a History". It provided daily entertainment for Manila residents, charging 85 [[Philippine peso|centavos]] for admission to one theatrical production and one movie. In addition to plays and movie showings, [[balagtasan]],{{cite journal|author=NLP |title=Literature in Spanish |url=http://nlpdl.nlp.gov.ph:9000/rpc/cat/finders/CC01/NLP00VM052mcd/v4/v5.pdf |work=[[National Library of the Philippines|NLP]] |publisher=National Library of the Philippines |accessdate=2 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502215338/http://nlpdl.nlp.gov.ph:9000/rpc/cat/finders/CC01/NLP00VM052mcd/v4/v5.pdf |archivedate=2 May 2014 |df= }} operas, concerts and ''[[bodabil]]'' (vaudeville) performances were occasionally staged in the complex. Ownership of the complex shifted from the heirs of Teodoro to former Philippine Ambassador to Laos [[Antonio Cabangon Chua]] in the 1960s, by which then the MGOH had become a cinema. Part of Cabangon Chua's plan for the complex include the construction of a hotel at the complex. As economic activity shifted from the Avenida area to [[Makati City]] in the 1970s, the MGOH was converted into what was then dubbed the largest [[nightclub]] in Manila: ''Chicks O'Clock'', catering to the working class near the Avenida area.{{cite news | author=Agustin, Victor C. | title=Grand Opera returns as a de-luxe hotel | url=http://www.manilastandardtoday.com/?page=business5_july14_2008 | work=[[Manila Standard Today]] | publisher=Kamahalan Publishing Corporation | date=2008-07-14 | accessdate=2008-08-10 }} The continued slump in Avenida eventually forced the closure of the club and the demolition of the theater. ===Manila Grand Opera Hotel=== [[File:WTMP A-trio b6 2.JPG|thumb|Manila Grand Opera Hotel and Casino]] Partially fulfilling Cabangon Chua's vision for the site and as a contribution to the revival of the Avenida area, the Manila Grand Opera Hotel was constructed on the site of the former MGOH. The eight-storey hotel opened in August 2008, with its second building opening sometime in 2009. It will be the only hotel with a direct connection to the [[Manila Light Rail Transit System Line 1]], connecting to [[Doroteo Jose LRT Station]], which is also rumored to be constructed on the MGOH grounds. ==See also== *[[Zorrilla Theater]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Manila Grand Opera House}} *[http://www.manilagrandopera.com/ Official website of the Manila Grand Opera Hotel] {{Manila hotels}} {{coord|14|36|19.73|N|120|58|53.63|E|region:PH|display=title}} [[Category:Hotels in Manila]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in the 19th century]] [[Category:Former buildings and structures in Manila]] [[Category:Theaters in Manila]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Santa Cruz, Manila]] [[Category:Opera houses in the Philippines]]

{{Infobox venue | name = Millmoor Ground | nickname = Millmoor | image = [[File:Millmoor Stadium 2015.jpg|250px]] | caption = An abandoned Millmoor in 2015, Rotherham | fullname = | location = Millmoor Lane
[[Rotherham]]
[[England]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | renovated = 1920, 1951, 2004 | expanded = 1920 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[C F Booth]] | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Rotherham County F.C.]] (1907–1925)
[[Rotherham United F.C.]] (1925–2008)
Westfield United F.C. (2016–Present) | capacity = 8,300 | record_attendance = 21,000 (Rotherham County FC vs [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], 1 November 1920){{cite web|url=http://www.martijnmureau.nl/vergane-glorie-millmoor-stadium/|title=Vergane Glorie: Millmoor|date=23 March 2016|work=Martijn Mureau|accessdate=}} | dimensions = {{convert|110|x|72|yd|m|1}} | scoreboard = }} The '''Millmoor Ground''', commonly known as '''Millmoor''', is a [[Association football|football]] stadium in [[Rotherham]], [[South Yorkshire]], England. It was the home ground of [[Rotherham County F.C.]] between 1907 and 1925 and then their successors [[Rotherham United F.C.]] until 2008. The stadium has had no professional tenant since, but has been in use again for local youth football since 2016. ==History== The stadium was in use during the 1890s, with Rotherham Church Institute using the ground in the [[Sheffield Association League]].Sheffield Independent, 15 November 1897{{cite web|url=http://www.themillers.co.uk//|title=Official website Rotherham United FC|date=23 March 2016|work=|accessdate=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322193609/http://www.themillers.co.uk/|archive-date=22 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} and presently has a capacity of around 8,300. Redevelopment work was started on the ground, with a new main stand being built in place of the previous wooden main stand which was built in the 1950s. The new stand was planned to contain corporate facilities and bring the capacity back to over 10,000. The work was scheduled to finish in 2006, but has faced a series of setbacks, one of which was [[Japanese knotweed]] being found on the site. Rotherham United have now moved to a [[New York Stadium|new community stadium]]. In May 2011 [[Rotherham R.U.F.C.|Rotherham Titans]] and [[Metropolitan Borough of Rotherham|Rotherham Council]] announced a plan to allow the [[rugby union]] club to move into Millmoor.{{cite web |url=http://www.rotherhamrugby.co.uk/News.php?id=a68884279e04bcb792d3afc0de75e1bb |title=Millmoor Deal A Step Nearer! |author=Rotherham Titans |date=6 October 2011 |work= |publisher=Rotherham Titans |accessdate=22 June 2011 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} After much speculation it was announced in December 2011 that the Titans would remain at [[Clifton Lane]] for the foreseeable future due to the deal falling through.{{cite web|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/rugby-union/millmoor_move_collapses_to_leave_rotherham_looking_for_new_home_1_4070438|title=Yorkshire Post Article|date=17 December 2011|work=|accessdate=}} Millmoor hosted a number of memorable Rotherham United games including a first leg of the inaugural Football League Cup final against Aston Villa in 1961, which Rotherham won 2–0. On 22 September 2007, for Rotherham United's game against [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]], it was a special day to celebrate 100 years at Millmoor. The game ended 1–1, with [[Peter Holmes (footballer)|Peter Holmes]] scoring for the Millers. There were special articles in the matchday programme and a commemorative cover. There were balloons all around Millmoor, with the Millers' badge, and the words '100 Years at Millmoor'. Fans were urged to wear retro Rotherham United shirts in order to be entered into a raffle. Many fans were seen with new scarves with Rotherham United F.C. on one side and 1907-2007 on the other side. In May 2008, Rotherham United were forced to leave Millmoor after talks with Ken Booth, owner of Millmoor, broke down.{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/end_of_an_era_millmoor_farewell_for_rotherham_1_2502707|title=End of an era: Millmoor farewell for Rotherham|work=[[Yorkshire Post]]|date=30 May 2008|accessdate=7 December 2013}} The team played in the [[Don Valley Stadium]] in [[Sheffield]] until 2012, when the club moved into a [[New York Stadium|new community stadium]] in Rotherham. Millmoor is currently used by Westfield United of The Bud Evans BD U18 Division 5 ==Structure and facilities== === Tivoli End === The Tivoli was a favourite amongst the fans. The stand holds up to 2,700. It was a former terrace but was later seated during the club's time in the [[Football League Championship]]. ===Railway End=== [[File:The Visitor's End at Millmoor, Rotherham - geograph.org.uk - 1229503.jpg|thumb|Away terrace in 1976]] The Railway End is the away fans section where over 2,000 fans can be accommodated. This end is covered and all seated. An unusual feature is that away fans can only access this end by going down Millmoor Lane, which is a narrow alleyway. The acoustics on the railway end are said to be some of the best and fans can generate a lot of noise. If needed, away fans can be given additional seats in a section of the Millmoor Lane stand. The railway referred to in the stand's name is the now closed line to the former [[Rotherham Westgate railway station]]. ===Main stand=== [[File:Stand under construction - geograph.org.uk - 336903.jpg|thumb|Stand under construction in 2005]] Redevelopment work was started on this stand, however that work has now ceased and in November 2007 the club confirmed that it had no intentions to complete this stand or modernise any part of the stadium due to the difficulty in reaching a deal to purchase the land surrounding Millmoor from the previous chairman. This dispute later led to Rotherham United moving away from the stadium. The stand remains partly finished. ===Millmoor Lane End=== Opposite to the Main Stand is the Millmoor Lane side of the ground. It is split up into three sections: *Tivoli end/Uncovered end - before the ground was all-seated in conformity with the rules of the [[Football League Championship]], the corner of the ground underneath the floodlights was a continuation of the terraces of the Tivoli End. When the section was all seated, the Tivoli End was split up into two parts for safety reasons: the part of the stand segregated from the Tivoli Stand is now simply called "The Uncovered End" due to the fact there is no roof over the heads of the home supporters housed there. *Millmoor Lane - in the middle of the Millmoor Lane side is the Millmoor Lane, which is a small stand for home supporters. ==Other uses== [[Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom|Greyhound racing]] took place at Millmoor Stadium from 11 May 1931 until 29 July 1933. The racing was independent (not affiliated to the sports governing body the [[National Greyhound Racing Club]]) and was known as a flapping track which was the nickname given to independent tracks.{{cite book|last=Barnes|first=Julia|title=Daily Mirror Greyhound Fact File|page =422|year=1988|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-15-5}} ==References== {{commons category|Millmoor}} {{Reflist}} {{Rotherham United F.C.}} {{English greyhound tracks}} {{Coord|53|25|42.12|N|1|22|12.83|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} [[Category:Rotherham United F.C.]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in England]] [[Category:Sport in Rotherham]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Rotherham]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in South Yorkshire]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1907]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] [[Category:1907 establishments in England]] [[Category:Defunct greyhound racing venues in the United Kingdom]]

Center field: {{convert|400|ft|m}}
Right field: {{convert|330|ft|m}} | publictransit = From CENTRO Transit Hub: #16, #116, or #216 ''N. Salina'' bus (center platform, Bay B8) }} '''NBT Bank Stadium''' is a publicly owned, 11,071-seat, [[minor league baseball]] [[stadium]] in [[Syracuse, New York]]. It is the home stadium for the [[Syracuse Mets]] [[Triple-A (baseball)|Triple-A]] baseball team of the [[International League]]. The stadium, owned and at times operated by [[Onondaga County, New York|Onondaga County]], opened on April 10, 1997, replacing the aging [[MacArthur Stadium]] which had served as home to Syracuse's professional baseball teams since 1934 and which was demolished in 1997. ==Mets baseball== {{Main article|Syracuse Mets}} The stadium is home to the Syracuse Mets, the Triple-A affiliate of the [[New York Mets]]. The field's outfield dimensions are {{convert|330|ft|m}} to left field, {{convert|400|ft|m}} to center field, and {{convert|330|ft|m}} to right field. The stadium has an official [[seating capacity]] of 11,071 people. In addition to regular seating, the stadium also offers luxury suites and a banquet room. The luxury suites are available in three different sized configurations and all include indoor and outdoor seating options as well as optional stadium-provided catering.{{cite web |title=Tickets - Luxury Suites|url=http://www.milb.com/tickets/page.jsp?ymd=20060210&content_id=41245&vkey=tickets_t552&fext=.jsp&sid=t552|publisher=[[Syracuse Chiefs]]|accessdate=August 12, 2009}} The stadium's banquet room is named after former baseball player [[Hank Sauer]] who was with the then Syracuse Chiefs in the 1940s prior to going on to excel in the Major Leagues into the late 1950s and eventually have his number retired by the team. The room is near the right field foul pole and is available to rent year-round.{{cite web |title=Tickets - Hank Sauer Room|url=http://www.milb.com/tickets/page.jsp?ymd=20060210&content_id=41247&vkey=tickets_t552&fext=.jsp&sid=t552|publisher=[[Syracuse Chiefs]]|accessdate=August 12, 2009}} Seating is broken down into the following: 280 in the 20 luxury suites, 3,000 in the 300 (upper) level, and 7,791 in the lower level.{{cite web |url=http://skychiefs.com/SkyChiefs/ticketinfo.html |title=Ticket Information - Syracuse SkyChiefs - AAA Baseball |website=SkyChiefs.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/19990209082216/http://skychiefs.com/SkyChiefs/ticketinfo.html |archive-date=February 9, 1999 |date=1998}}{{Failed verification|reason=Only one of the numbers is given, and it's in a different context.|date=August 2018}} From its opening through the 2007 season, the stadium's playing surface was [[AstroTurf]], mainly due to the team's then-affiliation with the [[Toronto Blue Jays]] who used the artificial surface in their ballpark. However, after the 2007 season, the Astro Turf was removed and replaced with natural grass.{{cite news |title=Put the Rug to the Curb and Get Growing|first=Bud|last=Poliquin|url=http://www.syracuse.com/poststandard/stories/index.ssf?/base/sports-0/1182675787223220.xml&coll=1|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=June 24, 2007|accessdate=June 26, 2007}} A record for baseball attendance was set May 7, 2010, when 14,098 people came to the park for [[Stephen Strasburg]]'s Triple-A debut.{{cite web |title=Syracuse 7 Gwinnett 0|url=http://web.minorleaguebaseball.com/milb/stats/stats.jsp?sid=t552&t=g_box&gid=2010_05_07_gwiaaa_syraaa_1|publisher=[[Syracuse Chiefs]]|date=May 7, 2010|accessdate=May 7, 2010}} On March 20, 2012, the Syracuse Chiefs announced a new videoboard would be installed by the time the Chiefs took on the Durham Bulls on May 7, 2012. The screen measures 30' X 55' (LED High Definition display), making it one of the largest video boards in the minor leagues.{{cite web |title=Syracuse Chiefs to Update Stadium With New Daktronics Video Display|url=http://syracuse.chiefs.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20120320&content_id=27439624&vkey=pr_t552&fext=.jsp&sid=t552|publisher=[[Syracuse Chiefs]]|date=March 20, 2012|accessdate=February 15, 2013}} The stadium's PA system also was upgraded. ==Other uses== ===Soccer=== The former [[soccer]] club [[Syracuse Salty Dogs]] of the [[United Soccer Leagues]]' [[USL First Division|A-League]] also called the stadium home for two seasons. Though they were very popular with fans and had very high attendance, their relationships with the Chiefs and Onondaga County were not positive and the team ceased operations after their second season. ===Concerts=== In 2009, the stadium played host to the first two national concerts held at the stadium since 2000 when [[The Allman Brothers Band]] played there.{{cite news |title=Online Ticket Request Period for Dave Matthews Band's August 4 Show at Syracuse's Alliance Bank Stadium Starts Today|first=Mark|last=Bialczak|url=http://blog.syracuse.com/listenup/2009/02/online_ticket_request_for_dave.html#more|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=February 19, 2009|accessdate=February 19, 2009}} On July 19, 2009, the stadium hosted 7,124 fans who came to see [[Bob Dylan]], [[Willie Nelson]], and [[John Mellencamp]] perform.{{cite news |title=Fans Approve of Alliance Bank Stadium as Concert Venue|first=Nina|last=Wegner|url=http://www.syracuse.com/entertainment/index.ssf?/base/entertainment-2/1248080133222280.xml&coll=1|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=July 20, 2009|accessdate=August 12, 2009}}{{cite news |title=Dylan Clearly Shows that He's a Man of Words at Alliance Bank Stadium in Syracuse|first=Mark|last=Bialczak|url=http://blog.syracuse.com/listenup/2009/07/dylan_clearly_shows_that_hes_a.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=July 19, 2009|accessdate=August 12, 2009}} Two weeks after the Bob Dylan concert, on August 4, [[Dave Matthews Band]] was scheduled to perform at the stadium.{{cite news |title=Dave Matthews Band to Play Alliance Bank Stadium|first=Brent|last=Axe|url=http://www.syracuse.com/axeman/index.ssf/2009/02/dave_matthews_at_alliance_bank.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=February 19, 2009|accessdate=August 12, 2009}} Stadium management said they used lessons learned during the smaller-scale Dylan show to make the much larger-scale Dave Matthews Band show as smooth as possible. The show drew over 18,000 fans and was considered a great success, possibly paving the way for more concerts at the stadium in the years to come.{{cite news |title=Thousands Flock to Syracuse's Alliance Bank Stadium to See Dave Matthews Band|first=Nina|last=Wegner|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2009/08/thousands_flock_to_syracuses_a.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=August 5, 2009|accessdate=August 12, 2009}} ===Hockey=== Following the success of the 2008 and 2009 [[NHL Winter Classic]] outdoor hockey games, [[Syracuse Crunch]] owner Howard Dolgan started expressing his interest in holding a similar event in Syracuse. Alliance Bank stadium was the logical location to hold such an event since it is the only outdoor professional sports venue in the area. The Crunch estimated the cost of such an event to be between $850,000 and $1.05 million.{{cite news |title=When You Hate Being Right|first=Brent|last=Axe|url=http://www.syracuse.com/axeman/index.ssf/2009/05/when_you_hate_being_right.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=May 29, 2009|accessdate=August 12, 2009}} That being the case, Dolgan decided to ask the [[Onondaga County]] legislature for some financial help in putting on the event. Dolgan argued that since the event was expected to bring many out of town hockey fans to Syracuse, the county could use $350,000 of money set aside "specifically to promote tourism and to attract out-of-town dollars to Syracuse".{{cite news |title=Howard Dolgan On the "Idiots"|first=Brent|last=Axe|url=http://www.syracuse.com/axeman/index.ssf/2009/06/howard_dolgon_on_the_idiots.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=June 2, 2009|accessdate=August 12, 2009}} The money in that fund is collected as a tax on hotel rooms in the county and could be replenished by the people coming in from out-of-town for the hockey game. However, the legislature voted 16-2 to not provide the $350,000 in funding and instead approved a total $75,000 in funding. Prior to the legislature's vote, Dolgan stated publicly that without the $350,000, the game would not go on. After the vote, Dolgan immediately turned the money down, stating:
We're not doing an outdoor game. I'll tell ya, besides disappointing the fans and, of course, our organization, I can tell you about 10–12 prominent companies in Syracuse who are not going to be happy because the idiots who voted the way they did. And I don't mind saying that word. What are they going to do? Get mad at me and vote against something else I want to do?
Eventually, the game was held at the New York State Fairgrounds on Saturday, February 20, 2010, as the "[[Mirabito Outdoor Classic]]". ===Scranton/Wilkes-Barre=== During the [[2009 IL Season|2009 International League Season]], the [[Scranton/Wilkes-Barre RailRiders]] (then known as the Scranton/Wilkes-Barre Yankees) were forced to postpone 11 games due to drainage problems at their home park, [[PNC Field]].{{cite news |title=Baseball Officials Inspect PNC Field|first=Jon|last=Meyer|url=http://www.wnep.com/wnep-lacka-baseball-officials-inspect-pnc-field,0,748907.story|work=[[WNEP-TV|WNEP]]|date=July 7, 2009|accessdate=August 12, 2009}}{{cite news |title=Yankees vs. Mets to Play Each Other at Syracuse's Alliance Bank Stadium|first=Mike|last=Waters|url=http://blog.syracuse.com/chiefs/2009/07/yankees_vs_mets_to_play_each_o.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=July 8, 2009|accessdate=August 12, 2009}} In an effort to allow groundskeepers ample time to repair the field, Scranton/Wilkes-Barre decided to relocate four of their home games. Two of these games, both against the [[Buffalo Bisons]], were moved to Syracuse.{{cite news |title=Home stand moved to Lehigh and Syracuse|url=http://community.thetimes-tribune.com/blogs/yankees/archive/2009/07/08/home-stand-moved-to-lehigh-and-syracuse.aspx|newspaper=[[The Times-Tribune (Scranton)]]|date=July 8, 2009|accessdate=August 12, 2009}} ==Economics== ===Construction=== Construction on the stadium was completed in 1997, at a total cost of approximately $28 million.{{cite news |title=Onondaga County Might Sell Alliance Bank Stadium to Syracuse Chiefs|first=Rick|last=Moriarty|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2012/01/onondaga_county_might_sell_all.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=January 19, 2012|accessdate=September 10, 2013}} ===Financing=== According to ''[[The Post-Standard]]'' newspaper, financing for stadium construction included: * $16 million from New York state taxpayers * $6.6 million from Onondaga County taxpayers * $4 million from the Syracuse Chiefs/ Community Baseball Club of Central New York, Inc. * $1 million from the [[Toronto Blue Jays]] (which was then the Chiefs' affiliated team) === Lease === In 2012, the Community Baseball Club of Central New York (Syracuse Chiefs) signed an 11-year lease of the stadium with [[Onondaga County]], starting at $126,000 per year, and increasing two percent per year through 2022, when it would pay $153,576. The Chiefs and County share maintenance, utility and other costs, with the former contributing about $500,000 per year to stadium upkeep. In its prior, 15-year lease, the Baseball Club paid no rent, but its $4 million contribution to the construction of the stadium was amortized over the term of the lease, in lieu of rent, amounting to about $22,222 per month ($266,664 per year). The Community Baseball Club had an "option to buy" the stadium from Onondaga County "by the end of 2013", at a price of $3.05 million.{{cite news|last1=Moriarty|first1=Rick|title=Chiefs ask county to cut stadium rent|publisher=The Post-Standard|date=20 March 2016|page=C-4|URL=http://www.syracuse.com/business-news/index.ssf/2016/03/still_losing_money_syracuse_chiefs_want_cut_in_rent_at_county-owned_stadium.html}}{{cite news |title=Syracuse Chiefs Get More Time to Purchase Alliance Bank Stadium|first=Rick|last=Moriarty|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2012/12/syracuse_chiefs_get_more_time.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=December 18, 2012|accessdate=September 10, 2013}} ===Naming rights=== [[NBT Bank]] pays Onondaga County $140,000 per year for stadium [[naming rights]]. The 20-year agreement continues through 2025.{{cite news |title=Alliance Bank Stadium Name Changing to NBT Bank Stadium|first=Rick|last=Moriarty|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2013/03/alliance_bank_stadium_name_cha.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=March 13, 2013|accessdate=September 10, 2013}} Jack Webb, executive vice president of NBT Bank and former president of Alliance Bank, serves on the board of directors of the Community Baseball Club of Central New York, Inc., owners of the Syracuse Chiefs and current operator of NBT Bank Stadium.{{cite news |title=To Escape Fiscal Crisis, Syracuse Chiefs' Board Considers Offers: One for $500,000, Another for $1 Million|first=John|last=O'Brien|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2013/09/syracuse_chiefs_board_considering_two_investment_proposals.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=September 30, 2013|accessdate=December 8, 2013}} Previously, the stadium was known as ''P&C Stadium'', derived from P&C Foods, the regional brand of supermarkets run by then Syracuse-based [[Penn Traffic]] Corporation (1997–2005); and ''Alliance Bank Stadium'' (2005–2013). In 2013, Alliance Bank merged with NBT Bank, which agreed to carry on the naming rights agreement. ===Video screen=== The stadium's high-definition digital video screen, installed in 2012, was purchased by the Chiefs with a bank loan of $950,000, with Community Baseball Club investments as collateral; and with a County contribution of $200,000. The loan was due January 31, 2014.{{cite news |title=Syracuse Chiefs Call for Help, But Is It Too Late|first=David M.|last=Rubin|url=http://blog.syracuse.com/opinion/2013/04/david_rubin_syracuse_chiefs_ca.html|newspaper=[[The Post-Standard]]|location=Syracuse|date=April 10, 2013|accessdate=September 10, 2013}}{{update inline|date=March 2016}} ===Renovation=== In August 2018 the New York Mets and Onondaga County discussed a renovation which could reduce seating capacity by a third while adding a greater array of amenities, with an eye toward extending the team's commitment to NBT Bank Stadium beyond the 2025 season.{{cite news |last1=Spedden |first1=Zach |title=NBT Bank Stadium Renovation Being Explored |url=https://ballparkdigest.com/2018/08/20/nbt-bank-stadium-renovation-being-explored/ |accessdate=August 20, 2018 |work=Ballpark Digest |publisher=August Publications |date=August 20, 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Knauss |first1=Tim |title=To keep Mets in CNY, Onondaga County seeks $25 million-plus stadium renovation |url=https://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2018/08/to_keep_mets_in_syracuse_county_eyes_major_makeover_for_nbt_bank_stadium.html |accessdate=August 20, 2018 |work=[[The Post-Standard]] |date=August 17, 2018}} At the same time, some local officials raised the possibility of constructing a new downtown ballpark.{{cite news |last1=Spedden |first1=Zach |title=New Downtown Syracuse Ballpark Debated |url=https://ballparkdigest.com/2018/08/31/new-downtown-syracuse-ballpark-debated/ |accessdate=August 31, 2018 |work=Ballpark Digest |publisher=August Publications |date=August 31, 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Knauss |first1=Tim |title=25 years later, debate resumes: Should CNY build a downtown baseball stadium? |url=https://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2018/08/should_syracuse_consider_building_a_new_downtown_baseball_park_again.html |accessdate=August 31, 2018 |work=The Post-Standard |date=August 30, 2018}} ==Gallery== File:SyracuseChiefsAtAllianceBankStadium.JPG|The [[Syracuse Chiefs]] playing the field during a game in 2009. File:Chiefs-fireworks-2016-0827.jpg|[[Fireworks]], NBT Bank Stadium in 2016. File:Saltydogssyr.jpg|A [[Syracuse Salty Dogs]] game at the stadium in 2004. File:Dave Matthews Band in Syracuse.jpg|[[Dave Matthews Band]] onstage in 2009. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|NBT Bank Stadium}} * [http://onondagacountyparks.com/nbt-bank-stadium/ Official Site] * {{cite web |title=Alliance Bank |url=http://www.ballparkwatch.com/visits/syracuse.htm |website=Ball Park Watch |archiveurl=http://archive.li/6L7nB |archivedate=September 27, 2007}} * [https://ballparkdigest.com/200902211446/minor-league-baseball/visits/alliance-bank-stadium-syracuse-chiefs Alliance Bank Stadium on ''Ballpark Digest''] * [http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2001/Syracuse/Syracuse.htm Alliance Bank Stadium Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] * [http://www.frontiernet.net/~rochballparks3/syracuse/alliance.htm Photographs of Alliance Bank Stadium - ''Rochester Area Ballparks''] * [http://www.ballparkreviews.com/template2.php?in_name=NBT+Bank+Stadium&in_city=Syracuse&in_state=New%20York BallparkReviews.com Photos and Review] (2010) * {{cite web |title=Syracuse stadium gets new name: NBT Bank Stadium Is the New Home of the Triple-A Chiefs |url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20130313&content_id=42681860&vkey=news_&fext=.jsp&sid= |website=MiLB.com |publisher=Syracuse Chiefs |accessdate=August 20, 2018 |language=en |date=March 13, 2013}} * {{cite news |last1=Moriarty |first1=Rick |title=Onondaga County lawmakers to vote on proposed new lease of baseball stadium by Syracuse Chiefs |url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2012/02/onondaga_county_lawmakers_to_v.html |accessdate=August 20, 2018 |work=syracuse.com |date=February 7, 2012}} {{s-start|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the [[Syracuse Chiefs]] | years = 1997 – present | before = [[MacArthur Stadium]] | after = Current }} {{end}} {{IL Ballparks}} {{Sports in Syracuse}} {{Syracuse, New York}} [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Syracuse, New York]] [[Category:Syracuse Chiefs]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1997]] [[Category:1997 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Soccer venues in New York (state)]]

The '''Women's Golf Coaches Association''' (WGCA) — formerly known as the National Golf Coaches Association<ref name=AboutUs>[http://www.community.wgcagolf.com/aboutwgca/overview About WGCA]. Women's Golf Coaches Association website. Retrieved on 2016-12-02.</ref> — is an organization formed in 1983 to promote women's [[college athletics|intercollegiate]] [[golf]]. The vision of WGCA since its inception has been "to encourage the playing of intercollegiate golf for [[women's sports|women]] in correlation with a general objective of education and in accordance with the highest tradition of intercollegiate competition".
==About== The WGCA has a membership of over 400 [[coach (sport)|coaches]] of [[NCAA Division I]], [[NCAA Division II|II]], [[NCAA Division III|III]], [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]], and [[National Junior College Athletic Association|NJCAA]]<ref>[http://www.njcaa.org/sports/wgolf/index Women's golf]. National Junior College Athletic Association website. Retrieved on 2016-12-02.</ref> collegiate programs.<ref name=AboutUs/>
WHCA is governed by a 13-member Board of Directors and the headquarters is located in [[Coral Springs, Florida]].
==Awards== The WGCA gives out many [[:Category:Golf awards|awards]],<ref>[http://www.ngca.com/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageid=3345 Overview: Honors & Awards]. WGCA website. Retrieved 2010-11-10.</ref> including: *[[NGCA National Coach of the Year]] *[[NGCA Assistant Coach of the Year]] *[[Gladys Palmer Meritorious Service Award]] *[[NGCA Founders Award]] *[[PING Player of the Year]] *[[NGCA Freshman of the Year]] *[[Edith Cummings Munson Golf Award]] *[[Dinah Shore Trophy Award]] *[[Golfstat Cup Award]] *[[Kim Moore Spirit Award]]
In addition, they also recognize [[All-American]]s as well as [[student athlete|scholar-athlete]] All-Americans and a panel of 33 coaches in the country vote for the rankings for DI, II & III each week.
==Hall of fame== Formed in 1986, the WGCA [[Hall of Fame]]<ref>[http://www.ngca.com/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageid=3294 NGCA Hall of Fame] webpage. NGCA website. Retrieved 2010-11-09.</ref> consists of a Coaches Hall of Fame<ref>[http://www.ngca.com/i4a/pages/Index.cfm?pageID=3357 Coaches Hall of Fame Inductees]. NGCA website. Retrieved 2010-11-09.</ref> and a Players Hall of Fame.<ref>[http://www.ngca.com/i4a/pages/Index.cfm?pageID=3296 NGCA Player Hall of Fame] members. NGCA website. Retrieved 2010-11-09. ''See also:'' [[World Golf Hall of Fame#Women]].</ref>
==See also== *[[NCAA Women's Golf Championship|NCAA Division I Women's Golf Championship]]

{{Refimprove|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = National Stadium | fullname = Supachalasai National Stadium | image = File:Suphachalasai Stadium 2015.jpg | location = [[Pathum Wan District|Wang Mai, Pathum Wan]], [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] | built = 1937 | opened = 1938 | renovated = | expanded = 1941 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Ministry of Tourism and Sports (Thailand)|Ministry of Tourism and Sports]] | operator = Department of Physical Education | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | tenants = [[Thailand national football team]] (selected matches) | seating_capacity = 19,793 {{cite web|title=สนามกีฬาศุภชลาศัย|url=http://stadium.satc.or.th/view/20|website=SATC|language=th-TH}} |publictransit = {{rint|bangkok|silom}} [[National Stadium BTS station|National Stadium]] | architect = Department of Physical Education }} The '''National Stadium''' of [[Thailand]] ({{lang-th|สนามกีฬาแห่งชาติ or กรีฑาสถานแห่งชาติ}}) is a [[sports complex]] located in [[Pathum Wan District]], [[Bangkok]]. Founded in 1937 with the construction of '''Supachalasai Stadium''' ({{lang|th|สนามศุภชลาศัย}}; {{RTGS|Supphachalasai}}), its main venue, the complex has since expanded and now consists of multiple stadia and sporting facilities. ==History== [[File:Bangkok National Stadium IMG 7300.jpg|thumb|left|In front of National Stadium]] It is used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. It served as the main stadium for the [[1966 Asian Games|1966]], [[1970 Asian Games|1970]], and [[1978 Asian Games]]. It was also used for the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup]], but only for one game (Oman v Iraq in Group A). The stadium is easy for spectators to get to as it is served by the [[BTS Skytrain]] which stops at the '[[National Stadium BTS station]]' right next to the stadium.https://www.fourfourtwo.com/th/features/aacchehluueaekhkhwaamthrngccham-80-pii-suphchlaasay-kabnaakhtchuengairkhamtb The stadium is a single tier construction which is uncovered on three sides. A plain but effective roof covers the main-stand side. Although there is a running track, the tribunes are immediately adjacent to it so spectators are not as far from the action as they are at the newer [[Rajamangala Stadium]]. Spectator comfort was increased in 2007 with the addition of red bench seats to the previously bare concrete steps on the three open sides.http://www.smmsport.com/m/article.php?a=9149 Thai league clubs often play at the Suphachalasai in Asian competitions as their own stadiums do not meet [[Asian Football Confederation]] criteria. However, it is now rarely used by the national team who usually play at the [[Rajamangala National Stadium]]. Other stadiums in Bangkok include the [[Thai Army Sports Stadium]], the [[Thai-Japanese Stadium]] and [[Chulalongkorn University Stadium]]. *Entertainer [[Michael Jackson]] performed 2 concerts there during his ''[[Dangerous World Tour]]'' on 24 and 27 August 1993 in front of 140,000 in attendance.[[Dangerous Tour]] {{Coord|13|44|44|N|100|31|32|E|type:landmark_region:TH|display=title}} ==Stadium Facility== ===Suphachalasai Stadium=== Suphachalasai Stadium is the majority part of the National Stadium. It is the [[multi-purpose stadium]] with [[track and field]] for athletic purposes, as well as a partial roof on one of its side. With its capacity of 19,793, the stadium is being used to hold important matches such as the [[Thai FA Cup]] and [[Thai League Cup]]. ===Thephasadin Stadium=== [[Thephasadin Stadium]] was constructed in 1965 for the use in [[1966 Asian Games]] as the Hockey venue, hence its original name, Hockey Field. It was renamed in 1983 in memorial of [[Chaophraya Thammasakmontri|Sanan Thephasadin na Ayutthaya]], considered the Father of Thai Football. With its capacity of 6,378 seats, it was retired from being the hockey stadium. ===Jindarat Stadium=== Jindarat Stadium, constructed after the [[Pacific War]], was formerly used as the outdoor stadium for medium-level sporting events and practicing purposes. It was originally named ''Ton Pho Stadium'', but was renamed in 1983 in memorial of Jindarat (Jamlong Sawat-chuto), former director of the Office of Sports and Recreation Development. ===Wisutamol Pool=== Wisutamol Pool was constructed in 1961 under the term of director Kong Wisutamol. It was the [[Olympic-size swimming pool]] with two sides of stands, used for the competition and general practices. Originally named the Olympic Pool, it was renamed in memorial of the director Wisutamol who organized the construction. ===Nimibutr Stadium=== [[Nimibutr Stadium]], opened in 1963 is an indoor stadium used for sports including boxing, badminton, gymnastics, futsal, basketball and handball. ===Jhanthana-Yingyong Gymnasium=== Jhanthana-Yingyong Gymnasium was built in 1965. == Notes and references == {{reflist}} == See also == * [[Rajamangala National Stadium]] ==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Suphachalasai Stadium}} {{S-start}} {{Succession box | title=[[AFC Asian Cup]]
